metadata.description: Consolidated poultry terminology extracted from University of Kentucky Poultry Glossary

contributors.definition: R. E. Buresh, F. B. Mather, and W. D. Weaver, Jr.

abdomen.definition: the ventral portion of the body approximately posterior to the ribs.

abdominal_capacity.definition: an evaluation of a hen (part of handling quality) giving an indication of the state of egg production. Determined by using the hand to estimate the distance between the ends of the pubic bones and between the tips of the pubic bones and the end of the keel (breast bone).

abdominal_cavity.definition: the posterior portion of the body cavity. It is often the site of excessive fat deposition. See also Thoracic cavity.

acclimation.definition: adaptation in response to a climatic variable, usually in controlled chambers.

acclimatization.definition: long-term physiological adaptation resulting in increased tolerance to repeated or continuous exposure to multiple climatic stressors, usually under natural conditions.

acidosis.definition: unusually high level of acidity in the blood or tissues.

acrosome.definition: the anterior pointed apex of the head-piece of the avian sperm.

acute.definition: a condition that is relatively short and severe, but not chronic.

adaptation.definition: physiological, behavioral, genetic or other changes that favor the welfare, survival and reproduction of an animal in a particular environment.

additive.definition: a substance added to the diet that is not a natural nutritive ingredient. This includes medications, pigments, flavorings, enzymes, prebiotics, probiotics, etc.

additive_gene.definition: a gene which has greater expression in the homozygous state than in the heterozygous state or which influences degree rather than kind of expression.

addled_egg.definition: 1) egg with mixed albumen and yolk, sometimes caused by shaking or jarring; 2) rotten or dead embryo.

adenovirus.definition: a group of viruses so-named because they were often isolated from adenoids and tonsils of humans. They are known to cause Inclusion Body Hepatitis, Aplastic anemia, Egg Drop syndrome, immune suppression and respiratory infections.

adjuvant.definition: additive to a vaccine to enhance its effectiveness.

ad_libitum.definition: available free choice at all times (e.g., feed or water). 1

adrenal_glands.definition: a pair of oval or triangular yellow glands located near the anterior tip of the kidneys. Produce several hormones including corticosterone, aldosterone, cortisone, adrenaline, progesterone, testosterone, estradiol, epinephrine, norepinephrine and others. Affects homeostasis, stress responses, reproduction, circulatory system, kidney and others. Involved in the “fight or flight” behavior.

aerobic.definition: bacteria that require air (oxygen) to grow.

aerosol.definition: a very fine mist produced by forcing a liquid through a small nozzle. It has application in spraying or fogging water or germicidal solutions in enclosed spaces such as incubators, rooms, and egg coolers.

aflatoxin.definition: toxins produced by various molds; often contaminate feed ingredients and prepared feed.

afterfeather,_aftershaft.definition: a secondary feather attached to the underside of a contour feather. Primary function is insulation.

agglutination_test.definition: microorganisms cause the body to produce antibodies that are found in the blood. An antigen for an organism mixed with a drop of blood will cause the agglutination or sticking together of antigen and antibodies, if the antibody for the microorganism is present, resulting in visible clumps. A positive test indicates that the bird has been exposed to the organism.

ahemeral.definition: artificial daylengths that are more or less than 24 hours.

air_cell_or_space.definition: a space between the inner and outer shell membranes, usually in the large end of the egg, which contains air. It can be used as one indication of age and quality of eggs for consumption. Embryologically, it provides an air source for the beginning of lung respiration before the shell is broken during the hatching process.

air_chilled.definition: cooling processed carcasses using cold air as opposed to cold water.

air_jet.definition: a stream of air coming from an air inlet in a negative pressure ventilation system.

air_sacs.definition: very thin-walled membraneous sacs containing air and connected with the lungs. Some act as bellows in the respiration process moving air through the lungs where gas exchange occurs. Some penetrate into the hollow bones. Minor functions include heat exchange and lightness. There are 9 in the chicken (paired cervical, cranial thoracic, caudal thoracic and abdominal, and an unpaired interclavicular) but the number varies across species.

albumen.definition: the white of an egg. The layers are chalaziferous (chalaza), which is attached to the yolk, inner thin, thick, and outer thin. It comprises approximately 60% of the egg weight and 67% of the contents in a chicken egg. The albumen furnishes most of the water and slightly more than half of the protein required by the embryo. 2

albumin.definition: a type of protein found in plants and animals, including egg albumen.

alkalosis.definition: unusually high level of alkalinity in the blood or tissues.

allantois_or_allantoic_membrane.definition: an embryonic membrane that grows from the umbilical area to the shell and fuses with the chorion membrane to form the chorioallantois membrane. This membrane grows around the inner surface of the shell enclosing all of the egg contents and embryo. Its primary functions are respiration, absorption of the albumen, waste containment, moisture exchange and mineral absorption from the shell.

allel.definition: one of a pair of genes that can occur at the same locus on a chromosome.

allergy.definition: hypersensitivity of a bird to a particular substance.

all_in_all_out.definition: a flock of birds enters and exits a facility as a single group. New birds are not introduced and flocks are not mixed. This strategy minimizes the risk of new birds introducing disease agents into a flock.

allometry.definition: the study and measurement of the size or growth of a body part relative to the whole body.

altricial.definition: birds that usually have little down at hatching and that are not mobile, thus unable to leave the hatching area. See Precocial, Nidicolous and Nidifugous.

american_standard_of_perfection.definition: a publication of The American Poultry Association, Inc. that describes each breed of poultry recognized by that organization; it is used as a basis for judging exhibition birds by breed.

amino_acid.definition: primary organic chemical units that combine to form various proteins. Those

considered_essential_in_the_diet_are.term: considered essential in the diet are
considered_essential_in_the_diet_are.definition: methionine, threonine, lysine, arginine, glycine, histidine, leucine, isoleucine, tryptophan, phenylalanine, and valine.

ammonia.definition: a gas (NH ) that is a common environmental pollutant in poultry houses. 3

amnion_or_amniotic_membrane.definition: a thin-walled embryonic membrane that completely encloses the embryo early in incubation. It is filled with a clear fluid (amniotic fluid) which bathes and protects the embryo. It provides shock absorption and prevents embryonic adherence to other egg structures.

anabolism.definition: process by which food is converted in living tissue to useful substances.

anaerobic.definition: bacteria that grow without air or oxygen.

anatidae.definition: the family of birds including ducks, geese, swans and others. 3

anatinae.definition: the branch of family Anatidae that includes ducks.

anatomy.definition: the science of the structure or morphology of an animal or other organism.

androgen.definition: hormone produced primarily in the testes and is involved in semen production and the presence of male secondary sex characteristics.

anemia.definition: an abnormally low number of red blood cells in the circulatory system.

anemometer.definition: an instrument used to measure air speed; usually in feet per minute (fpm).

animal_and_plant_health_inspection_servi.term: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS)
animal_and_plant_health_inspection_servi.definition: the USDA agency that oversees animal health, importation and exportation.

anion.definition: an ion having a negative charge. See also Cation.

anionic_detergent.definition: a substance having disinfectant activity because of the presence of an active negatively-charged ion or group.

annual_cycles.definition: birds under natural conditions go through cycles of feather molting, fat deposition, reproduction, and migration. There are wide variations among species in these cycles. The cycles are influenced by light, temperature, rainfall, food availability, global location and other factors.

anophthalmia.definition: a condition in some embryos in which the eyes are absent.

anorexia.definition: low appetite or loss of appetite.

anserinae.definition: the branch of family Anatidae that includes the goose.

antemortem_inspection.definition: inspection of birds just before slaughter.

anthelmintic.definition: a drug to treat against parasitic worms (helminthes), mainly in the intestinal tract.

antibiotic.definition: a substance produced by a microorganism that destroys or inhibits growth of bacteria or other microorganisms. Used to treat bacterial diseases and for growth promotion of the bird. A broad-spectrum antibiotic affects multiple types of microorganisms.

antibody.definition: a protein produced by the body in response to exposure to a foreign substance, or antigen, which will neutralize the antigen and provide immunity. 4

anticoccidial.definition: a drug or chemical used to prevent or treat coccidiosis.

antigen.definition: a substance to which the body reacts to produce an antibody.

antioxidant.definition: a substance which reduces oxidation of fats, oils and other compounds; removes and prevents buildup of metabolic byproducts which have toxic effects. They may be added to the feed prior to storage to maintain vitamin potency. Vitamins C and E have antioxidant properties.

antipyretic.definition: a substance that will reduce fever.

antirachitic.definition: prevents rickets; vitamin D is antirachitic.

antiseptic.definition: a substance that has antimicrobial properties but may not kill them.

antiserum.definition: serum from an animal that has a high titer against an antigen and which, when injected into another animal, will confer a low level of passive immunity.

antitoxin.definition: serum from an animal that has a high titer against a specific toxin and which, when injected into another animal, will confer some protection against that toxin.

aorta.definition: large artery exiting the heart carrying oxygenated blood to the body.

aortic_rupture.definition: tearing of the aorta or main artery leaving the heart causing sudden death. Turkeys and very heavy birds are most susceptible.

arboreal.definition: adapted to tree-living; living in trees.

area_opaca.definition: in the early stages of a developing blastoderm it is the white outer ring surrounding the inner translucent area (area pellucida) in which the embryo first forms.

area_pellucida.definition: in the early stages of a developing blastoderm it is the central translucent area in which the embryo first forms, and which is surrounded by a white ring (area opaca).

area_vasculosa.definition: the area around the early embryo in which blood is first formed; blood islands form, and then develop into a vascular system that is connected to the embryo.

artery.definition: vessels that transport blood away from the heart. Compare Vein.

artificial_insemination.definition: a technique in which semen is collected from the male and deposited, with or without dilution, in the vagina of the female. Currently used in almost all 5 commercial turkey breeding operations, in some exotic bird species, and in research and pedigree matings.

ascarid.definition: the round worm that infests the small intestine. See Roundworm.

ascites.definition: a condition (pulmonary hypertension syndrome) found in higher incidence in broilers grown at higher altitudes, somewhat similar to congestive heart failure with right ventricular dilation. Usually results in accumulation of fluid in the abdominal cavity and increased mortality.

ascorbic_acid.definition: vitamin C; an antioxidant, not considered to be essential in the diet of birds because it is produced in the body.

aspergillosis.definition: an infection, commonly in the respiratory tract, caused by the fungus, Aspergillus; causes morbidity, and is some cases, high mortality. Young chicks are very susceptible, often acquiring the infection from the litter in the brooding area or while still in the hatchery. Also called brooder pneumonia.

ataxia.definition: lack of coordinated muscular movements as in epidemic tremors or “crazy chick disease”.

atlas.definition: the vertebra of the spinal column which articulates with the skull.

atresia.definition: degenerative changes or absorption of ovarian follicles.

atrophy.definition: decrease in size or strength or the wasting away of tissue or organs, as by nutritional deficiency, disease, or physiology (normal or abnormal).

attenuate.definition: to lessen in severity. Attenuated micro-organisms may be used for vaccination with an associated mild occurrence of the disease.

auger.definition: 1) a mechanical device for moving feed or other material through a tube using the screw principle, similar to Archimedian screw. 2) Also a tool for boring holes.

auricle.definition: one of the top two chambers of the heart; an atrium; the right receives deoxygenated blood from the body and the left receives oxygenated blood from the lungs.

autosexing.definition: determining the gender of the chick by a characteristic such as feather color or feather growth. Obtained by using sex-linked genetic characteristics.

autosome.definition: any chromosome that is not a sex chromosome.

available.definition: in respect to nutrients, it is that part or form of nutrient (e.g., phosphorus) which can be absorbed and utilized by the body.

avian_encephalomyelitis.definition: an infectious viral disease characterized by ataxia and tremors of the head and neck, usually in young chicks. Also called Epidemic Tremors.

avian_influenza.definition: a respiratory disease caused by a virus similar to those causing human influenza. The mild form causes decreased egg production and low mortality, whereas the acute form causes high mortality and affects multiple body systems.

aviary_system.definition: a management system that usually includes deep litter, perches and slatted floor at various levels as an alternative system to battery cages.

avidin.definition: a protein found in small amounts in egg albumen that has a capacity to bind biotin.

avitaminosis.definition: a condition caused by a vitamin deficiency. Hypovitaminosis may be more correct in many cases.

axial_feather.definition: a small feather between the primary and secondary flight feathers on the wing.

b_cells.definition: lymphocytes derived from the bursa of Fabricius and produced in the bone marrow. Involved with humoral immunity.

bacillary_white_diarrhea.definition: disease caused by the bacterium Salmonella Pullorum resulting in high mortality in embryos and young chicks. Controlled by blood testing breeding stock and removing reactor birds identified by agglutination test, use of antibacterial agents on eggs, and strict sanitation programs.

bacitracin.definition: antibiotic used in poultry and other species

backcross.definition: a breeding procedure in which a crossbred is mated to one of its parents or parental types.

backyard_flock.definition: a small, noncommercial poultry flock kept for home use, showing, or other purposes.

bacteria.definition: single-celled micro-organisms containing no chlorophyll that often cause diseases.

bactericide.definition: a substance that has capability of killing bacteria.

bacterin.definition: a suspension of killed bacteria used to produce immunity when injected.

bacteriocins.definition: peptide compounds produced by ribosomes of some bacteria that have a narrow range of antimicrobial activity.

bacteriostat.definition: a substance that prevents bacteria from propagating. 7

baffled_ventilation.definition: baffles or obstructive devices in the poultry house air intake prevents direct air flow and moderates rate of flow.

balanced_diet.definition: a diet formulated to contain all known essential nutrients in amounts necessary for ideal growth, development, production and health for a specific type of bird, age of bird, and intended use for the bird. Efficiency of utilization, excess excretion, and economics are also considerations.

bantam.definition: a small type of chicken, many of which are dwarfs of standard breeds; usually are ornamental breeds.

bantam_standard.definition: a publication of the American Bantam Association that describes the characteristics of bantam poultry; used as a basis of judging exhibition birds.

barb.definition: the branches or projections from either side of the rhachis or shaft of a feather, which in turn have barbules and barbicels as substructures.

barbicels.definition: hooks and flanges of the feather barbule. Flanges are on the proximal side and hooks on the distal side of the barbule.

barbule.definition: projections from either side of the feather barb, each with the substructures, barbicels.

barnyard_chicken.definition: a chicken of mixed breeds; common in small home flocks.

barring.definition: alternate stripes across the feather in some breeds. It can be determined by an autosomal gene, as in Dominiques, or sex-linked dominant gene, as in Barred Plymouth Rocks. Sex-linked barring can be used for autosexing purposes.

basal_metabolic_rate_(bmr).definition: the minimal heat production of a normal bird that is awake, resting, and fasting (post-absorptive state) at an ambient temperature causing neither regulatory thermogenesis or energy for active evaporative cooling (thermoneutral zone). Standard metabolic rate (SMR) is with birds resting, fasting and in a temperature below thermoneutral zone. Resting metabolic rate (RMR) is measured when birds are resting but not fasting and may be at a temperature below thermoneutral zone.

basted.definition: the industry practice of injecting a specific volume of liquid into raw poultry and poultry parts to improve tenderness, juiciness, or flavor and to improve cooking time.

battery_cages.definition: cages, usually made of wire, that are used to keep hens or growing birds. They may be stacked in moveable units or in stationary long rows of one or more levels.

beak.definition: the upper and lower mandibles of a bird forming the forward mouth parts. See Bill.

beak_trimming.definition: removing a portion of the beak tip to reduce feather pecking, cannibalism and egg eating. Usually accomplished with a machine that cuts and/or cauterizes the beak. It often is done with young chicks and usually involves only the upper beak but in some procedures both upper and lower beaks are trimmed. 8

bean.definition: 1) a hard, rounded bulge on the tip of the upper bill of waterfowl. 2) Also the seed of some plants, many of which are edible.

beard.definition: 1) cluster of enlarged feathers growing from the throat area; 2) also applies to the tuft of long, coarse string-like feathers on the central breast of the adult male turkey.

bedding.definition: wood shavings or other material placed on the floor of a pen to absorb manure and moisture. See Litter.

bevy.definition: a flock of quail or swan.

bile.definition: a green, viscous secretion of the liver; stored in the gall bladder; released into the posterior duodenum; involved in digestion, especially of lipids.

bill.definition: the upper and lower mandibles of waterfowl forming the mouth. See Beak.

billing_out.definition: use of the beak or bill to knock feed out of a feeder.

bioassay.definition: quantitative or qualitative determination of a substance using living test subjects.

bioavailability.definition: the proportion of the ingested element that is absorbed, transported to the site of action and converted to a physiologically active form.

biochemical_oxygen_demand_(bod).definition: a quantitative measure of the oxygen needed by bacteria and micro-organisms for the biological oxidation of organic wastes in a unit volume of waste water.

biocide.definition: a substance poisonous to living organisms.

bioclimatology.definition: the science concerned with the effects of climate on living organisms.

biosecurity.definition: procedures such as sanitation and isolation used to prevent disease exposure to birds or premises.

biotin.definition: water-soluble vitamin essential to the bird. It is especially vital for normal embryonic development and normal skin and foot pads in chicks.

bird.definition: an animal of the class Aves that is two-legged, warm blooded, egg-laying vertebrate with wings and feathers (the most unique characteristic).

blackhead.definition: the disease Enterohepatitis Histomoniasis, more common in turkeys and some game birds; common symptoms are sulfur colored droppings, lethargy, and liver lesions. See Histomoniasis, Heterakis and cecal worm. 9

black_out_house.definition: houses that do not allow any natural light into the building

black_vomit_(vomito_negro).definition: a toxic condition more common in Central and South America. A black fluid is often found in the crop, proventriculus and gizzard. The cause appears to be poor quality fish meal.

blade.definition: the lower, unserrated portion of the single comb.

blast_freeze.definition: rapid lowering of carcass temperature, usually with very cold air (about 30C) with exposure time varying with temperature. Also referred to as Quick Freeze or Deep Freeze.

blastoderm.definition: the early-stage developing embryo, which appears macroscopically as a donut shaped spot on the yolk at the time of oviposition. It is underneath the vitelline membrane. See Germinal disc.

blastodisc.definition: the germinal area of a nonfertilized ovum; it appears on the surface of the yolk as a small white spot.

bleaching.definition: fading of the yellow pigment from the skin, beak, shanks and vent of a hen during egg production.

blood_group.definition: birds classified according to antigens produced and determined by blood agglutination tests.

blood_islands.definition: beginning of the formation of blood and circulatory system in the embryo.

blood_ring.definition: a crescent-shaped ring of blood accumulated near the shell of eggs in which the embryo died during early stages of incubation.

blood_spots.definition: inclusions in the egg albumen or on the yolk surface that are comprised of blood from the ovary or pieces of tissue from the ovary or oviduct. See Meat spots.

blood_streaks.definition: blood smeared on the eggshell surface during oviposition resulting from bleeding from the oviduct.

blood_test.definition: blood collected for agglutination (e.g., pullorum test) or other types of tests.

bloom.definition: the gloss or shine of the outer surface of the eggshell, primarily because of the cuticle. See Cuticle.

blowout.definition: damage and collapse of the vent and oviduct; usually caused by the laying of an oversize egg. 10

wax_plucking.definition: a bird carcass is dipped into melted wax, which is allowed to cool and then stripped off to remove the feathers. Used primarily for waterfowl.

weather.definition: day-to-day variations of meteorological variables, whereas climate is the long- term expression of weather.

web.definition: 1) Part of the feather on either side of the shaft consisting of barbs (see Vane). 2) Flat skin between the toes, especially in waterfowl. 3) A triangular stretch of skin on the wing front between the shoulder and the wrist.

wet_bulb_thermometer.definition: a thermometer with the bulb covered with a wet cloth or gauze used to measure relative humidity. When placed in moving air the evaporation of moisture from the cloth cools the thermometer and when compared to a dry-bulb thermometer temperature using tables (see Psychrometric chart) the relative humidity can be determined.

whey,_dried.definition: a product produced from the thin milk portion remaining from cheese- making and other procedures. It can be used as a feed ingredient.

whole_carcass_rinse_(wcr).definition: method of determining presence of Salmonella, Campylobacter and other microbes on post-chill poultry carcasses.

whole_eggs.definition: consist of yolk and albumen. For the various egg product classes – liquid, frozen and dried – the yolk and albumen are separated during the breaking process and later remixed to formulate whole eggs in accordance with customer specifications.

windpuff.definition: air from a punctured air sac that accumulates under the skin of the neck and anterior body. The air can be released by puncturing the skin with a sterile needle.

wing.definition: the forelimb of the bird. Developed for flight in most birds whereas in others it is used for swimming or balance in running.

wing_band.definition: a metal or plastic identification tag fastened to the wing web or around the upper wing or humerus (wing badge).

wishbone.definition: a common name for the v-shaped clavicle bone in the breast.

withdrawal_diet.definition: the diet fed to birds for a specified time prior to slaughter and contains no antibiotics or other compounds that might be undesirable in the meat for human consumption.

wog.definition: whole young poultry without giblets and neck in the bird’s net weight. WOG refers to With Out Giblets. They may be split, quartered or cut into 8 or 9 pieces for the fast food/service business. 91

xanthophyll.definition: a fat soluble yellow pigment found in plants that is deposited in the skin, fat, and egg yolk giving them a yellow color. Synthetic pigments are available to provide the same type coloring. See Pigmentation.

xerophthalmia.definition: a conjunctivitis condition of the eye caused by a vitamin A deficiency.

yolk.definition: the ovum of the bird containing yolk material and the living cell or blastoderm. The avian yolk is polylecithal (much yolk) and telolecithal (living portion on one pole and only that portion divides). It is contained in the yolk membrane (see Vitelline membrane).

yolk_sac.definition: the embryonic membrane that grows around the yolk enclosing it and that is involved in digestion and absorption of yolk material. It is pulled into the abdominal cavity (yolk sac retraction) of the 19-day embryo (chicken) where absorption continues for a few days following hatching.

yolk_spheres.definition: closely packed polygonal sac-like structures containing yolk material that make up the major portion of the egg yolk.

zoonotic_diseases.definition: those that can be transmitted from animals to man.

zygote.definition: the fertilized egg before development (cleavage) begins. Fertilization occurs in the infundibulum of the oviduct.

additional_sources.definition: Forscey, L.A. 1969. Multi-Lingual Poultry Dictionary. European Federation of Branches of the World’s Poultry Science Assoc., Edagricole Bologna, Italy. Malone, P., G. Donnelly, W. Leonard. 1998. The American Standard of Perfection. American Poultry Assoc., Inc., Mendon, MA. [newer editions are available] European Federation of the World’s Poultry Science Assoc. 1983. Terms used for parts

of_poultry_in_different_languages._world.term: of poultry in different languages. World’s Poult. Sci. J. 39
of_poultry_in_different_languages._world.definition: 64-73. Lewis, P.D. and G.C. Perry. 1990. Glossary of avian photoperiodic terminology and

methods_of_expressing_lighting_regimens..term: methods of expressing lighting regimens. Br. Poult. Sci. 31

blue_eggs.definition: eggshells with blue to green color; characteristic of the Araucanas breed but has simple inheritance and thus can be bred into any other breed. One pigment involved is oocyan.

bobwhite_quail.definition: relatively small ground-dwelling game birds (Colinus virginianus) of N. America that are raised domestically for stocking hunting preserves and to a lesser degree for meat and eggs.

body_check.definition: an egg with the shell broken while still in the hen’s oviduct.

body_temperature.definition: most domestic birds thermoregulate to a body temperature of 41 to 42°C (105.8 to 107.6°F). Some birds, such as ostrich, have lower temperature and others will become temporarily torpid. The upper lethal body temperature in the chicken is 115 to 116.6°F (46.1 to 47.0°C).

bone.definition: the hard dense tissue of the skeleton comprised primarily of calcium and phosphorus with a protein matrix.

boning.definition: removal of the muscle, fat and skin from the skeleton. Also called deboning.

booted.definition: feathers on toes, shanks and hocks. Feather legged.

botulism.definition: a pathological paralytic condition caused by consumption of a toxin produced by Costridium botulinum. Sometimes referred to as “limber-neck”.

brain.definition: large mass of neural tissue located in the head; part of the central nervous system; the coordinating center of impulses received and transmission of impulses sent.

brassy.definition: a yellowish tint sometimes seen in white-feathered birds.

breakers.definition: companies that process eggs into egg products.

breaking_eggs.definition: shell eggs designated for cracking (breaking) to produce egg products

break_out.definition: examination of unhatched eggs following incubation to determine the cause of failure to hatch.

break_up.definition: actions taken to prevent a hen from incubating eggs.

breast.definition: the chest portion of the bird consisting primarily of the clavicle and keel bones and the flight muscles (Pectoralis major and pectoralis minor).

breast_blister.definition: a water cyst or blister on the breast along the keel; often caused by poor litter conditions. 11

breed.definition: 1) a group of birds having similar body shape and weight characteristics and when mated together produce offspring with those same characteristics. A breed may contain one or more varieties that are distinguished by different comb, color or other specific trait. 2) To mate and produce offspring.

breeder.definition: 1) a sexually mature bird used for breeding purposes to produce eggs for hatching. 2) Also, a person, company, or organization that breeds poultry.

breed_true.definition: the characteristic of a group of birds, or breed, in which the offspring exhibit the same identifying qualities as the parents.

brewer’s_grains.definition: the residual materials from grains used in the brewery industry that can be used as a feed ingredient.

broad_spectrum.definition: an antibiotic or drug that is effective against several microorganisms.

broiler.definition: a young meat type bird that can be cooked in a variety of ways, including frying, baking, and broiling. The most common type of chicken meat marketed as whole, cut-up, further processed entrees, and by fast food restaurants. Most commercial strains are primarily derived from Cornish and Plymouth Rock breeds.

broiler_breeder.definition: breeders that produce hatching eggs for commercial broiler production.

bronchi.definition: large air passages of the lungs.

bronze.definition: a metallic copper color seen in feathers of some chickens and turkeys and describes the color of the Bronze turkey.

brood.definition: 1) a group of birds hatched at the same time and cared for together by the parent. 2) To sit on eggs for incubation or to provide protection, food and water for the chicks.

brooder.definition: a heating unit that provides supplemental heat in a draft-free house for young birds.

broodiness_or_broody.definition: maternal behavior of the bird in which there is a desire to sit on eggs for incubation and care for the young. It has been decreased in commercial strains by genetic selection. See Brood patch.

brooding.definition: providing heat, shelter, food and protection for a flock of birds. A brooding hen is one that is caring for her young chicks.

brood_patch.definition: an area on the breast that loses feathers in a brooding hen allowing skin contact with eggs being incubated. Vasodilation of skin in this area may occur to increase temperature to the eggs. 12

broody_coop_or_cage.definition: a small enclosure in which broody hens are placed to induce them to stop broody behavior.

btu.definition: British thermal unit. The heat required to raise the temperature of one pound of water from 39°F to 40°F. One mean BTU = 252.1 calories = 1054.8 joule.

buff.definition: a medium yellow-orange shade of feather color.

built_up_litter.definition: “deep litter” that has accumulated through use for multiple flocks, usually with selective removal and addition of fresh litter on top of the old.

bulk_feed.definition: feed transported loose, i.e., not in bags; usually unloaded by auger into large bins at the farm.

bumblefoot.definition: an infection of the footpad of a bird causing swelling and lameness; usually caused by a Staphylococcus infection.

bursa_of_fabricus.definition: a dorsal diverticulum of the cloaca that provides the site for early embryonic and chick ontogeny and the expansion of B-lymphocytes.

cackle.definition: the sounds (including cak, cak, cak) characteristically made by a hen following the laying of an egg.

cage.definition: a relatively small enclosure, usually made of wire, in which birds are maintained for growth or egg laying. The birds are not in contact with the ground or their feces.

cage_house.definition: a house in which birds are maintained in cages without access to the ground and most of which have automatic feeders, waterers, and egg collection.

cage_layer_fatigue.definition: a weakness or paralysis in laying hens kept in cages caused by calcium and phosphorus imbalances in a period of high egg production, with phosphorus being most important. Other factors may also be involved.

calciferol.definition: vitamin D ; less potent than D in poultry. 2 3

calcium.definition: a major mineral constituent of the diet that is required for bone deposition, shell formation and numerous other functions.

calorie.definition: the quantity of heat required to raise the temperature of 1 gram of water 1C. Calorie level in the diet is commonly expressed as kilocalories per pound, kilocalories per kilogram and megajoules per kilogram of feed. One calorie = 4.185 joules.

calorimeter.definition: an instrument for measuring the amount of heat liberated or absorbed. 13

candidiasis.definition: fungal infection of the mouth, esophagus and crop commonly caused by Candida albicans, a fungus. See Thrush.

candle_or_candling.definition: examination of intact eggs with a light to determine internal conditions of incubated eggs (presence of an embryo, developmental stage of the embryo, presence of contamination, etc.). Table eggs are also candled to detect and remove eggs with cracks, blood spots, and other blemishes. Candling may be done with a hand-held light source (candler) or automatically by machines.

canker.definition: infected spots in mouth and throat, often with exudate. Common in the wet form of fowl pox.

cannibalism.definition: behavior pattern that includes pecking of pen-mates, especially around the tail or vent, and resulting in various degrees of injury or in death. Causes are often due to nutritional imbalances and management problems. The use of beak trimming, low light intensity, “spectacles”, and medicated salves in isolated cases, may alleviate the problem.

cape.definition: short feathers underneath the hackle at the juncture of the neck and back.

capillary_worms.definition: small, slender, hair-like worms that infest various parts of the intestinal tract of the bird, especially the crop. They may occasionally enter the trachea. They do not require an intermediate host. Heavy infestation may result in loss of weight, hemorrhage and death.

capon.definition: a young male chicken with testes removed with the intention to cause the bird to have more desirable meat. With current genetic stocks, nutrition and management there is little if any advantage to the use of capons. Plumage patterns and color resemble those of the male. Compare Poulard.

caponization.definition: the surgical procedure for removing testes of young male chickens.

carcass.definition: all edible parts of a slaughtered animal, including edible viscera.

carnivorous.definition: eating mostly animal matter, including insects.

carotenoid/carotene.definition: yellow and red pigments found in many plants and in some animal tissues. Some, such as beta-carotene can be converted into vitamin A in the body. They are the primary pigments responsible for the yellow color of egg yolks, fat, and skin.

carotid_artery.definition: blood vessel carrying blood to the head and neck.

carriers.definition: animals that can be the source of disease organisms even though they show no symptoms of the disease. 14

caruncles.definition: an outgrowth or protuberance of the skin on the head and neck of turkeys and Muscovy ducks.

case.definition: a container used in commercial practice for packaging eggs. The standard sized case will hold 30 dozen (360) eggs.

casein.definition: a phosphoprotein obtained from cow’s milk that is the basis for cheese and can be used as a feed ingredient.

caseous.definition: like cheese. Type of exudate seen in some infections.

cassava.definition: an ingredient used as a dietary energy source in some geographical areas. It is produced from roots of a tropical plant having a high starch content. Also known as manioc and tapioca.

castration.definition: removal of testicles or ovary resulting in capon or poulard, respectively. Reproductive organs may also be rendered nonfunctional by chemicals.

catabolism.definition: a process in which animal tissue is broken down into simpler compounds or waste products.

catalyst.definition: a substance that changes the rate of a chemical reaction without being changed itself.

cecal_tonsils.definition: lymphoid tissue at the base of the ceca at the illeocecal junction.

cecal_worms.definition: Heterakis gallinae is a small roundworm that is found in the ceca. It is often a carrier of Blackhead. See Heterakis and Blackhead.

cecum_or_ceca_(plural).definition: paired, closed, narrow pouches branching from the gut at the junction of the small and large intestine. Site of fermentation and digestion, especially of fiber. The contents are periodically evacuated and have a characteristic odor and smooth consistency. Blind gut.

cell_mediated_immunity.definition: immunity that depends on T-cells produced by the thymus, which are sensitized by exposure to a specific antigen. See T-cells.

cellulitis.definition: inflammation of the cellular or connective tissue.

cellulose.definition: a fibrous, complex carbohydrate that is a main constituent of plant cell walls. Most poultry species digest cellulose poorly. Some digestion occurs in the ceca.

central_nervous_system.definition: neural tissue of the brain and spinal cord that coordinates the activities of the bird through connection with the other parts of the nervous system. 15

cere.definition: the enlarged, unfeathered, waxy, fleshy area around or above the nostrils of birds such as pigeons, budgerigars and waterfowl.

cereals.definition: seeds of plants used for food and feed. Common cereals are corn, wheat, rice, sorghum, oats and barley.

cerebellum.definition: section of the brain behind the cerebrum that is involved in coordinating muscle movement.

cerebrum.definition: prominent forebrain that consists of two lobes responsible for voluntary actions, communication and thought processes.

cestodes.definition: commonly known as tapeworms. Segmented worms found in the intestinal tract. Usually have intermediate hosts such as beetles, worms, and larvae.

chalaza.definition: twisted strands of thick albumen that immediately surround the egg yolk forming the chalaziferous layer, attaching the yolk to the albumen and keeping it oriented and centered in the egg during egg storage and early incubation.

challenge.definition: to expose birds to an antigen.

check.definition: an egg that has a broken shell or crack in the shell but has its shell membrane intact and the egg contents are not leaking.

chemesthesis.definition: a sense based on chemically induced pain.

chemical_senses.definition: there are three classes of senses with a chemical basis: gustation or taste, olfaction or smell, and chemesthesis or chemically induced pain.

chemotherapy.definition: use of substances, such as antibiotics, that inhibit or destroy disease organisms with less damage to body tissue.

chick.definition: the young of chickens, pheasants, quail and other birds.

chicken.definition: the domestic fowl, Gallus domesticus, used for meat, eggs, feathers and showing. There are several hundred recognized breeds of various sizes, only a few of

which_are_important_for_meat_and_eggs._t.term: which are important for meat and eggs. There are four known species of wild chickens
which_are_important_for_meat_and_eggs._t.definition: Red Junglefowl (Gallus gallus or G. bankiva), Grey Junglefowl (Gallus sonnerati), Ceylon Junglefowl (Gallus lafayettei), and Green Junglefowl (Gallus varius). The Red Junglefowl has more in common with the domestic chicken than do the other types. 16

chick_guard.definition: a circular fence about 18 inches high placed around a brooder to keep young chicks near the heat and to eliminate corners.

chick_go_round.definition: a rotary table(s) used in servicing (sexing, vaccination, etc.) newly hatched chicks.

chilling_tank.definition: a large container in which processed birds are cooled in ice water prior to packaging.

chill_pack.definition: a form of refrigeration in which processed raw poultry products are chilled to 26 to 32°F (-3.3 to 0.0°C) degrees and packed in containers without being covered with ice.

chlamydiosis.definition: disease caused by Chlamydia psittaci called ornithosis in turkeys and psittacosis in psittacine birds, and can cause influenza-like disease in humans.

chlorination.definition: the application of chlorine to water, sewage, or industrial wastes, generally for the purpose of disinfection.

choice_feeding.definition: supply more than one type of feedstuff at the same time so that the bird may choose which type of feed to consume.

cholecalciferol.definition: vitamin D , the most active form in the bird. 3

cholesterol.definition: a crystalline, fatty alcohol found in animal tissue and products such as eggs. It may serve as a precursor for vitamin D . 3

choline.definition: a vitamin of the B complex group required by the bird for normal growth.

chorioallantois.definition: embryonic membrane formed from the fusion of chorion and allantois membranes. It grows around the inner surface of the inner eggshell membrane. Primary functions include embryonic respiration, absorption of albumen, absorption of shell minerals and protein, embryonic waste repository, and regulation of water loss.

chorion.definition: embryonic membrane that grows toward the shell and fuses with the allantois to form the chorioallantois by about the end of the first quartile of incubation. See Chorioallantois.

chondrodystropy.definition: embryonic abnormality that includes shortened and bent bones in legs and wings, general dwarfism, parrot-like upper beak, and internal organ malformations. Caused by nutritional deficiencies or heredity.

chromosomes.definition: paired, rod-like structures in a cell nucleus that contain the genes.

chronic.definition: an acute disease condition that becomes extended for several days or weeks is then considered to be chronic. 17

chronic_respiratory_disease_(crd).definition: a respiratory system disease caused by pleuro- pneumonia-like organisms. It may occur in many different species of birds, at various ages, and may persist for various periods of time in a flock. Mortality may be quite variable.

chukar.definition: an Asian partridge (Alectoris graeca) that is grown domestically and used by some hunting preserves as a game bird.

circadian.definition: rhythms that approximate 24 hours. Physiological functions that recur in a pattern throughout a 24-hour period, for example, body temperature, hormone levels, blood component levels, etc.

circulatory_system.definition: heart and blood vessels (arteries and veins) that circulates blood to all parts of the body. It carries oxygen and nutrients to tissues and wastes away from tissues; it also carries endocrine products and is involved in heat removal and conservation.

classification.definition: grouping of breeds according to their “class” or origin as defined in the American Standard of Perfection.

clavicle.definition: “wishbone”; the V-shaped bone in the breast.

clean_legged.definition: having no feathers on the shanks or feet. Compare with Feather Legged and Booted.

clears.definition: candling rejects; infertile or early dead hatching eggs identified by candling.

climatic_chamber.definition: a room or cabinet with controlled environmental conditions, such as temperature, humidity, light, and air flow, that is generally used for experimental purposes.

cloaca.definition: the combined external opening for the digestive, urinary and reproductive

systems._there_are_three_areas_of_the_cl.term: systems. There are three areas of the cloaca
systems._there_are_three_areas_of_the_cl.definition: the coprodeum or anterior area in which the digestive system empties; the urodeum or middle area in which the ureters of the urinary system enter dorsally and the vas deferens of the male or the oviduct of the female enter laterally; and the proctodeum, which is the external opening (vent) of the cloaca.

closed_flock.definition: a flock or group of birds bred from generation to generation without the introduction of new gene sources.

close_feathered.definition: feathers are held flat or close to the body.

clot.definition: a gelatinous clump of blood cells and other components resulting when blood is withdrawn from the circulatory system or escapes during trauma and the clot formation mechanism is initiated. 18

cloudy_white.definition: albumen of an egg that has a light colored foggy appearance. It can be associated with CO buildup in the egg. 2

clubbed_down.definition: feathers with little or no growth out of the follicle and having a stubby appearance. A riboflavin deficiency in the egg is considered to be one cause of the condition in the embryo/chick.

clutch.definition: an egg or a group of eggs produced by the female before incubation begins; the eggs to produce a brood. A clutch may consist of one or more egg sequences. It is sometimes confused with egg sequence. See Egg Sequence and Brood.

clutch_interval.definition: the time between clutches or broods.

cobalamin.definition: a group of chemically similar compounds containing cobalt in their structure and having anti-pernicious anemia activity. Vitamin B is such a compound. 12

coccidiosis.definition: intestinal disease caused by various species of protozoa (coccidia). Some species are specific to certain portion of the intestinal tract and they may be specific to a bird species.

coccidiostat.definition: drugs that reduce the number of coccidia and the effects of coccidiosis.

cock.definition: a male chicken or fowl more than one year old. Sometimes applied to males from the time of full sexual maturity. Also called Rooster.

cockatrice.definition: a mythical creature or serpent hatched by a reptile from a cock’s egg.

cockerel.definition: a male chicken or fowl less than one year old. Sometimes applied to males up to full sexual maturity.

coddled_egg.definition: egg broken out and cooked in water that is lower than boiling.

coefficient_of_inbreeding.definition: the mathematical expression of the degree of inbreeding present in an individual or group of birds.

colibacillosis.definition: a clinical infection caused by Escherichia coli. May cause enteritis, colisepticemia, airsacculitis, infection of the oviduct, peritonitis, perihepatitis, pericarditis, coli-granuloma and omphalitis.

columbian.definition: a plumage pattern in chickens consisting of white except black in the neck, primary wing, and tail feathers.

columella.definition: the single bone in the ear of a bird. 19

comb.definition: a fleshy protuberance on the top of the head of chickens and some other species. It is a secondary sexual characteristic, being much larger and more colorful in males. The

types_include.definition: single, rose, pea, buttercup, cushion, strawberry, v-shaped, and Silkie.

comfort_zone.definition: range of environmental conditions such as temperature, humidity and air flow, in which an animal appears to have physical and mental well-being. See also Thermoneutral zone.

commodity_packed.definition: whole or fresh young ready-to-cook poultry which have little or no values added and are generally prepared for retail and consumer markets.

competitive_exclusion.definition: epithelial associated or bound microorganisms that prevent contact between the epithelial cells and pathogenic bacteria. In the control or prevention of disease, it is normally associated with populating the gut with desirable, nonpathogenic organisms and thus blocking or ‘excluding’ the population of more pathogenic organisms.

complementary_genes.definition: two or more independent genes that must be present to produce a specific effect.

complete_feed.definition: nutritionally balanced feed mixed for specific animals and ready to be consumed

composting.definition: a natural decomposition process for organic wastes

concentrates.definition: dietary mixtures containing high protein, minerals and vitamins that are combined with cereals or other ingredients to provide a balanced feed.

condensed_fish_solubles.definition: a by-product of fish meal production that is a good source of some vitamins but may be low in some amino acids.

conduction.definition: heat transfer by direct contact of the body with an object or substance.

congenital.definition: condition existing at or before hatch or birth. May imply an inherited condition.

contagious.definition: a disease capable of being transmitted to a new host.

contour_feathers.definition: those with a stiff vane or web; a small down portion may be present in the anterior part of the web.

contract_growing.definition: a common form of broiler production in which the producer furnishes buildings, equipment, utilities and labor and the contractor (usually a processing complex) furnishes chicks, feed, medications, harvesting, and consultations. Payment is usually by a formula agreed upon in the contract. Similar arrangements are made for pullet production, hatching egg producers and table egg producers. 20

controlled_environment_housing.definition: a poultry house equipped with temperature, light and air quality control.

convection.definition: the transfer of heat from a warmer to a cooler surface by using the air between the surfaces, usually the upward movement of warm air.

coop.definition: house, pen or cage in which a bird is placed for transportation or to live.

copulation.definition: sexual union or intercourse of male and female.

corn.definition: in the western hemispheres corn refers to maize, whereas elsewhere it may refer to whole cereal grains including maize, wheat, oats, etc. It is a primary ingredient in most poultry diets. Although it contains approximately 9% protein, it is generally considered the primary source of energy in the diet. See Maize.

corn_belt.definition: the area of the U.S. where corn is a principal crop including Iowa, Indiana, Illinois, Kansas, Kentucky, Missouri, Nebraska, South Dakota, Minnesota, Ohio, and Wisconsin.

corn_germ_meal.definition: the germ of the corn kernel remaining as a byproduct from the manufacture of corn starch.

corn_gluten.definition: the outer covering of the corn kernel remaining as a residue from the manufacture of corn starch. It does not include the germ.

cornish.definition: a breed of the English Class of chickens having large skeleton and heavy breast muscles. They are used as the base male stock for commercial meat type chickens.

cornish_game_hen.definition: a meat type chicken having at least 25% Cornish blood that is processed at a young age and small body weight as a specialty product. Similar to Poussin.

corn_soya_diet.definition: a diet with maize and soybean meals as the major ingredients.

corpus_luteum.definition: the post-ovulatory follicle of the ovary. It may have a function in oviposition, however, it has little in common with the mammalian corpus luteum in regard to function.

coryza.definition: an upper respiratory infection especially affecting the nasal passages, sinuses and eyes. Caused by the organism Hemophilus gallinarum).

coturnix_quail_or_japanese_quail.definition: a small asian ground-dwelling bird (Coturnix coturnix japonica) that has been bred and used commercially for meat and egg production. In nature they are migratory. The breast meat is dark. 21

coverts.definition: feathers that cover the base of primary wing, secondary wing, and main tail feathers.

cracks.definition: eggs with breaks in the shell.

cramming.definition: a system of individually force-feeding birds to produce fattened table birds or livers for pate de foie gras. See Noodling.

creeper_fowl.definition: an inherited condition (heterozygote) in which the bird has shortened leg bones. The homozygous dominant condition is lethal.

crest.definition: a rounded tuft of feathers on the top of a bird’s head; it is usually more fully expressed in birds having a knob or round bony structure on the head.

crop.definition: the enlarged portion of the esophagus located at the base of the neck and outside of the body cavity. The primary function is food storage.

crop_bound.definition: a condition in which the crop is filled with material (impacted) that is not moved on through the digestive system.

crop,_pendulous.definition: a crop extended with material and hanging in front of the bird’s breast. It is more common in turkeys.

crop,_sour.definition: the material in the crop is not evacuated and becomes fermented with a sour or foul odor.

crossed_beak.definition: an abnormal condition in which the upper beak (maxilla) is curled to one side and misaligned with the lower beak (mandible).

crosses,_crossbreds.definition: progeny resulting from the mating of two varieties, breeds, or genetic stocks.

crow_head.definition: a narrow, shallow head and beak.

crude_protein.definition: calculation of the protein content of a feed or feed ingredient based on analysis for nitrogen. The amount of nitrogen is multiplied by 6.25 (on average, proteins contain 16% nitrogen).

crude_fiber.definition: that portion of a feed or feed ingredient that remains insoluble (primarily cellulose) after treatment with hot sulfuric acid and then hot potassium hydroxide, minus the ash. 22

crumbles.definition: feed with particle size intermediate between mash and pellets. Usually pelleted feed that has been partially broken. See Pellets.

cryptomere.definition: a genetic character that is not expressed because of masking by another gene.

cull.definition: an unthrifty or unproductive bird; not up to standard; usually removed (or culled) from the flock.

curled_toes.definition: a condition in chicks that is characteristic of a riboflavin deficiency.

cushion.definition: a large mass of feathers over the back and base of the tail in some breeds resulting in a rounded appearance.

custom_hatching.definition: hiring another hatchery to do incubation and chick services.

cuticle.definition: the outer layer of the eggshell, primarily protein; its function is to partially seal the shell to prevent bacterial invasion and excessive water loss. See Bloom.

cyanogenetic_glucoside.definition: a toxin found in linseed meal.

cyanosis.definition: bluish color of the skin usually associated with low levels of oxygen in the blood caused by poor ventilation and gas exchange.

cyclopia.definition: an embryonic abnormality characterized by the presence of one, median, eye and usually associated with other head abnormalities.

cyst.definition: a closed, abnormal sac in the body usually filled with fluid or semi-solid substance that is caused by abnormal development, disease or parasite.

cytology.definition: branch of biology dealing with cells, their structure, morphology, physiology, pathology, etc.

dam_family.definition: siblings that have the same dam or mother.

dander.definition: small particles of dead skin and feather particles.

dawn.definition: the dark/light interface that the bird senses as the beginning of the light period.

daylength.definition: the period of time between dark/light interface and light/dark interface that the birds senses as the day or light period. May also refer to the 24-h day in contrast to ahemeral day.

day_old.definition: short, industry jargon for one-day-old chick or poult 23

ddgs.definition: see Distillers dried grains with solubles.

dead_in_shell.definition: embryo that died during incubation without exiting the shell.

debeak.definition: a term sometimes used for beak trimming.

debone.definition: removal of the muscles and soft tissues from the bones during processing of the carcass. Also called boning.

deep_litter.definition: also called “built-up litter”; poultry house litter that is allowed to remain in the house for extended periods of time with periodic removal of wet areas and addition of some fresh litter. It can be managed so that it composts in place and is relatively free of pathogenic organisms. See Litter.

degree_day.definition: difference above and below the freezing temperature (32°F); thus a daily mean temperature of 68°F = 36 degree days for that day.

dehydration.definition: loss of water; body has a water deficit.

delmarva.definition: the peninsula of land in the U.S. where Delaware, Maryland and Virginia converge. This area is situated between the Atlantic Ocean and the Chesapeake Bay, which is also referred to as the Eastern Shore. This area has historically supported a large volume of commercial broiler production.

denester.definition: equipment that separates stacked boxes or packaging materials.

depletion.definition: process of emptying or loss of fluid or substance.

depluming_mite.definition: Cnemidocoptes Gallinae; a small mite that is found in the skin at the base of feathers. The irritation causes the bird to peck or scratch the feathers, damaging or pulling them out.

depopulation.definition: removal of all animals from a premise.

dermestes_maculatus.definition: a beetle that bores into wood and sometimes is found in poultry houses.

dermis.definition: layer of skin underneath the epidermis or outer layer.

designer_eggs.definition: eggs produced to contain higher levels of certain constituents, such as omega-3 fatty acids.

determinate_layer.definition: birds that do not vary the number of eggs per clutch; eggs lost or broken are not replaced. Most of this type lay small clutches of 3 eggs or less, e.g., pigeons with 2 eggs and petrels with one egg. See Indeterminate layer.

developer_diet.definition: the diet fed to growing pullets for several weeks prior to the time of the beginning of lay (sexual maturity).

dewlap.definition: a drooping growth of skin under the beak or bill and extending down the throat. Found in turkeys and some geese and chickens.

diapause.definition: the period of the embryo’s life from the time the egg is laid until placed in an incubator or the hen begins incubation. A time of little or no development.

diet.definition: food in the form of nutrient components or ingredients provided in very specific amounts and proportions. Sometimes called a Ration.

differentiation.definition: change from a relatively generalized to a more specialized tissue during development; an increase in complexity and organization and in specialization of function.

digestible_energy.definition: total energy of a feed less the energy remaining in the feces.

digit.definition: a toe of the foot or “finger” of the wing; a phalange.

dimorphic.definition: males and females of a species have visible differences in plumage, usually in shape and color, and in size with males being larger in most domestic species.

direct_fed_microbials_(dfm).definition: cultures of viable microbes (e.g., Lactobaccillus, Pediococcus and Bifidobacterium) that, when fed, have a beneficial effect on the host by influencing intestinal microflora (e.g., by competitive exclusion), and enhancing immune response, nutrient absorption, control of pathogens, or other means. Also known as Probiotics.

disease.definition: a departure from the healthy condition that adversely affects the proper functioning of tissues, organs or systems. Causes include infectious agents, metabolic conditions, nutrition, genetics, environment and toxins.

disinfect,_disinfectant.definition: the use of a material (the disinfectant) to kill or inactivate harmful organisms.

display.definition: behavioral movements of birds during courtship prior to mating, for example, the male turkey fans the tail feathers and wings, engorges the caruncles and struts prior to mating.

dissolved_air_flotation_(daf).definition: method of removing oil and suspended solids

distal.definition: part located away from the main body. 25

distillers_dried_grains_plus_solubles_(d.definition: the residual product from distilling grains to produce ethanol that can be used as a poultry feed ingredient.

diurnal.definition: during the day or light period.

domesticate.definition: to cause animals to adjust to living under the control of man for food or other purposes.

dominance,_genetic.definition: a character that suppresses its allele in the heterozygote individual. In incomplete dominance the allele is only partially suppressed.

dominance,_social.definition: status of individuals within a flock; those with high status in the peck order.

dorsal.definition: the back, or toward the back or upper surface of the body.

double_yolk.definition: an egg having two yolks, usually the result of two ova being ovulated at the same time. It may also result from one ovum not being picked up by the infundibulum on the day of ovulation.

down.definition: 1) the fluffy feathering of newly hatched chicks. 2) A fluffy type of feather in adults that functions as insulation.

drawdown_of_air_cell.definition: the change in shape and extent of the air cell that occurs just prior to the internal pipping of the membranes in the beginning of the hatching process.

dress,_dressing.definition: related to preparation of the carcass for cooking. See Processing.

drip_loss.definition: the loss in weight of a carcass following chilling in ice water, primarily due to the loss of water.

droppings.definition: the feces of birds; a partial white coating consists of urates; dark brown, smooth feces is usually of cecal origin; the remainder is from the large intestine.

drumstick.definition: that portion of the leg having the tibia and fibula bones; the distal half of the cooked leg. 26

dry_bulb_temperature.definition: ambient temperature measured without effect of humidity.

dry_matter.definition: that portion of feedstuffs remaining after all moisture has been removed.

dual_purpose_breed.definition: a breed that has relatively good egg production as well as moderate fleshing. The male chicks are usually grown out for meat purposes. They are often used for home flocks but are not economical for commercial purposes.

dub,_dubbing.definition: removal of the comb, usually in very young chicks. Wattles may also be removed. Practiced to prevent injury in breeds with very large combs, especially single combs.

duck.definition: small to moderate sized fowl (waterfowl) with web feet of the Anatidae family that are used for meat, eggs and feathers. There are several domestic breeds and species as well as many wild species.

duct.definition: a tube or canal that carries fluid or secretions from a gland or organ.

duodenum.definition: the first portion of the small intestine posterior to the gizzard, in a U-shaped loop with the pancreas attached in the loop.

dusk.definition: the light/dark interface that the bird senses as the end of the light period.

dust,_dust_bathe.definition: birds make a depression in dry, dusty soil and stir up the dust to get it under the feathers and on the skin. A natural activity that is thought to discourage parasites.

dwarf.definition: a smaller than usual version of any type bird, which may be an abnormality or may be intentionally produced. Some are abnormalities in embryos, which are lethal.

ear.definition: the organ of hearing. Unlike mammals, there is only one bone (the columella) in the ear of the bird. Usually covered externally by small feathers.

ear_lobe.definition: a fleshy area of bare skin below the ears in some species; may be white, red, blue or other color.

earthnut.definition: groundnut or peanut. Can be used as a feed ingredient.

ectoparasite.definition: a parasite that lives and feeds on the external surface of the host. Mites, lice and fleas are common poultry ectoparasites.

ectopic_viscera.definition: a malformation in embryos in which the body cavity is open thereby exposing the internal organs. 27

edema.definition: fluid accumulation in cells, tissues or cavities of the body, resulting in swelling.

effluent.definition: the liquid that comes out of a water treatment facility after completion of any treatment process

egg.definition: the reproductive cell of the female bird. The major parts are yolk with germinal cell, albumen, membranes, and shell. All of the nutritional elements necessary for embryonic development are present in the egg. Only the blastoderm (germinal cell) is living tissue.

egg_bound.definition: a complete egg that the bird was unable to lay causes subsequent eggs to accumulate in the oviduct, body cavity, or both.

egg_dipping.definition: a procedure in which warm eggs are submersed in a cool liquid containing antibiotic, hormone, or other active substance that is drawn into the egg as it cools and contracts.

egg_drop_syndrome.definition: an adenovirus-caused disease in laying birds characterized by severe decreases in egg production accompanied by eggshell abnormalities.

egg_flat_or_tray.definition: molded plastic or paper, commonly containing 30 cone-shaped molded cups, each holding one egg placed small end down. These are placed in cases or boxes for moving and storage. Many sizes and special designs are available for use in specific incubators as setter trays.

egg_sequence.definition: the eggs laid on consecutive days before skipping a day or more. Contrast Clutch.

egg_shell.definition: the hard calcareous coating of the egg that functions to provide physical protection, a barrier to microorganisms, gas exchange (oxygen, carbon dioxide and water vapor) for the embryo, and a source of nutrients (especially calcium) for the embryo. The shell is approximately 95% mineral of which 97 to 98% is calcium carbonate with small amounts of magnesium carbonate and tricalcium phosphate.

egg_sizes.definition: in the U.S. shell eggs are divided by size into classes according to weight.

minimum_weights_per_dozen_eggs_are.term: Minimum weights per dozen eggs are
minimum_weights_per_dozen_eggs_are.definition: Jumbo (30 oz), Extra Large (27 oz), Large (24 oz), Medium (21 oz) and Small (18 oz).

egg_tooth.definition: a temporary pointed tip that develops on the upper beak of the embryo and which the embryo uses in breaking through the shell in the process of hatching. It is shed shortly after the chick hatches.

egg_turning.definition: the practice during incubation of turning the egg around the long axis if incubated in a horizontal position or around the short axis if incubated with the large end up (as in most incubators). The common turning interval is once per hour at a 45° angle. 28

egg_yolk_peritonitis.definition: inflammation or infection of the peritoneal cavity caused by the presence of unabsorbed yolks that were not engulfed by the infundibulum.

ejaculate.definition: the semen, including sperm and fluids, that is discharged (ejaculated) by the male during Copulation.

electrolyte.definition: a solution, usually of a mineral, capable of carrying an electrical charge.

elutriation.definition: a method of particle separation based on size or weight and movement in an air stream. Air washing or air classification.

emaciated.definition: the body is excessively lean and in poor condition as seen in nutritional deficiencies.

embryo.definition: in the bird it is the period of development in the egg from one cell to hatching. Some development may occur at 76°F (24.5°C) with normal development in the chicken at approximately 99.5°F (37.5°C). The ideal developmental temperature varies slightly due to age of the embryo, species and other environmental conditions.

emu.definition: a large flightless bird (Dromiceius novae-hollandiae) of Australian origin similar to the ostrich, but smaller, that is used some for meat production.

encephalomalacia.definition: neural degeneration due to a vitamin E deficiency. Also called Crazy Chick disease. Results in lack of muscle coordination.

encephalomyelitis.definition: also known as Epidemic Tremors. Affects the brain and nervous system and may result in ataxia, prostration and death. Caused by a virus infection.

endemic.definition: commonly present in a particular population or geographical location.

endocrine_glands.definition: glands that produce internal secretion(s) that are carried by the blood to other tissues whose actions and functions they affect. Examples are thyroids, pituitary, adrenals, pancreas, gonads, and intestine.

endogenous.definition: originates or develops within the body.

endoparasite.definition: a parasite that lives and feeds in the internal tissues of the host. Roundworms and coccidia are examples.

energy.definition: the caloric value of food; used for heat production, muscle activity, enzymatic activity, reproduction and other physiological functions. Total energy may be divided into metabolizable energy, productive energy, etc. See Metabolized energy. 29

energy_protein_ratio.definition: the balance of energy and protein in the diet necessary to permit maximum efficiency of production of meat, eggs, or other products.

enteritis.definition: an inflammation of the intestine, especially of the small intestine. See Necrotic enteritis and Ulcerative enteritis.

entrainment.definition: the physiological change of an internal rhythm of the bird to synchronize it with an external phenomenon, such as a light cycle.

environment.definition: the conditions and influences surrounding a bird that affect it in some way. Broadly, nutrition and all other factors except genetics could be included, but in practice temperature, humidity, air flow, space, light, microbial population and pollutants are considered environment.

enzyme.definition: protein or protein-like substances that act as an organic catalyst to initiate or speed up physiological reactions, usually specific to that enzyme. Most become inactive in high temperatures.

epigenetic.definition: DNA changes that alter the way genes are turned on and off without altering genetic information.

epinephrine.definition: adrenaline, a hormone secreted by the medulla of the adrenal glands. Stimulates the heart, increases muscular strength and endurance, increases blood pressure, etc.

epistasis.definition: suppression of the normal expression of a gene by one or more other genes. For example, the inheritance of white in the White Leghorn breed results in the barring gene not being expressed. The gene suppressed is Hypostatic.

epithelium.definition: cellular tissue that forms the covering of the body surface, body cavity and hollow organs; includes several types of cells and occurs in one or more layers.

ergonomics.definition: the study of problems of workers adjusting to their environment and the science of adapting the working conditions to best suit the workers, especially anatomically.

ergosterol.definition: a substance found in ergot and yeast that, when exposed to sunlight, is transformed into vitamin D , which is not very active in poultry. 2

ergot.definition: toxic substances produced by certain fungi in grains, especially rye. 30

erysipelas_(erysipelothrix_septicemia).definition: a disease caused by a streptococcus that is more common in young turkeys (often characterized by an injured and swollen snood).

erythrocyte.definition: red blood cells or corpuscles. They contain hemoglobin and transport oxygen to tissues. Avian erythrocytes contain a nucleus whereas mammalian erythrocytes do not. One mL of blood will contain about 3 million erythrocytes.

esophagus.definition: the tube connecting the mouth with the crop and proventriculus and through which food is moved by gravity and peristaltic action.

essential_oils.definition: plant extracts such as clove and cinnamon that have some anti-microbial activity.

estivate.definition: induce torpidity by heat and dryness as opposed to hibernation in the cold.

estrogen.definition: hormone(s) secreted by the ovary and in small amounts by the adrenal. Affects blood lipids, calcium, and other constituents, influences the formation of egg components, and affects numerous physiological activities. It also refers to synthetic compounds with estrogenic properties.

ether_extract.definition: weight loss (%) of a substance following extraction with ether. It gives an approximation of fats and oils in the sample, although other substances are also soluble in ether.

etiology.definition: the study of the cause and origin of diseases.

european_production_efficiency_factor_(e.definition: a measure of the efficiency of broiler production.

evaporative_heat_loss.definition: the heat energy absorbed by water or other substance as it changes from a liquid or solid to vapor. Latent heat.

eversion.definition: partial expelling of the cloaca from the body. This is natural in laying of the egg but may abnormally remain outside of the body.

evisceration.definition: removal of organs from the body cavity during dressing and processing of a bird for meat purposes.

excreta.definition: waste matter excreted or eliminated from the body; feces and urine.

excrete.definition: to remove waste substances from the tissues and eliminate from the body.

exhibition_breed.definition: breeds and varieties of poultry selected for the purpose of exhibiting in shows. They are judged on standards established by recognized organizations that included the breeders. 31

expeller_process.definition: extraction of oil from seeds such as soybeans using heat and pressure.

exploder.definition: eggs that explode during incubation, usually because of contamination.

exsanguination.definition: removal of blood from the body.

extender.definition: a vegetable protein product added to meat products. May also apply to materials added to vaccines to increase the number of vaccine doses, and semen to increase insemination doses.

extension_service.definition: established in the U.S. in 1914 by the Smith-Leaver Act, it is a cooperative organization including federal, state, and county funding and personnel. The purpose is to teach and advise consumers, producers and others, provide publications, help solve practical problems, and to act as intermediary among industry, consumers, and research personnel.

external_parasites.definition: organisms such as fleas, lice, ticks and mites that live on the outside of the bird’s body and feed on the bird. See Ectoparasite.

extra_embryonic_membranes.definition: membranes that develop outside of the embryonic body; they are the amnion, chorion and allantois (chorioallantois), and yolk sack. Each of the membranes has one or more vital functions during the process of embryonic development.

exudate.definition: fluid or material that abnormally passes through vessel walls and accumulates in tissues. They sometimes have diagnostic value.

exudative_diathesis.definition: edema in subcutaneous tissue caused by deficiencies of selenium or vitamins.

eye.definition: the organ(s) of vision. Birds are visually dependent and tend to have larger eyes relative to body size. The ostrich has the largest eye and focal length of any land animal.

eyelids.definition: the moveable folds of tissue that cover and uncover the eye, provide protection to the eye, and keep the eye moist. See Nictitating membrane.

eye_stripe.definition: a dark marking in some birds, especially chicks, that surrounds the eyes and may go toward the back of the head. Sometimes considered to be a wild type of marking.

family_selection.definition: genetic selection program based on performance of family as well as the individual. For example, a female would be selected for egg production on the basis of her own record and that of her full sisters and a male could also be selected on egg production based on the record of his full sisters.

fan.definition: a device for causing movement of air, as in a ventilation system. Effectiveness can be measured as air flow rate (e.g., cubic feet per minute). 32

fancier.definition: a breeder of exhibition type birds used for showing.

fast_food_broiler.definition: young chickens with live weights of 4.20 lb and lighter. Without giblets (WOG), these birds should weigh between 2.40 and 2.90 lb.

fat_deposits.definition: birds tend to deposit fat around the internal organs, and especially in the abdominal body wall. Diets are formulated to minimize these economically wasteful deposits.

fat_soluble_vitamin.definition: vitamins soluble in fats and oils include A, D, E and K.

fatty_acids.definition: any of several unsaturated or saturated monobasic organic acids that occur in the form of glycerol esters in fats and oils. Some are considered essential nutrients.

fatty_liver_syndrome.definition: excessive lipid accumulation in the hepatocytes of the liver of laying hens causing the liver to be friable and easily ruptured.

favus.definition: infection of the skin, especially of the head and comb; caused by a fungus (Achorion gallinae or Trichophyton schoenleini).

feather.definition: outer covering of the bird’s body; modified scales attached to the skin in follicles. Feathers are a unique anatomical feature of the bird. Under natural environmental conditions the bird will replace (molt and re-grow) most feathers one or more times a year. Laying hens are managed in later production stages by induced molting and rejuvenation of the reproductive system.

feathering.definition: usually implies the amount and quality of the feather covering of a bird.

feather_legged.definition: having feathers on the outer side of the shanks and on some toes. See Booted.

feather_tracts.definition: the areas of the skin from which feathers grow. See Pteryla.

feces.definition: excreted waste matter from the digestive tract. However, the term as commonly used includes the urine as well because the urine is not voided separately by the bird. See Droppings.

fecundity.definition: fertility; may refer to the number of eggs laid over a certain period of time, to the number of fertile eggs produced, or to the number of chicks produced.
