feed.definition: “to feed” is to provide food for the bird. However, it is just as commonly used to mean the food provided. Also referred to as diet or ration.

feed_conversion_ratio_(fcr).definition: the amount of feed required to produce a unit of body

weight_increase,_a_unit_of_weight_of_egg.term: weight increase, a unit of weight of eggs, or a dozen of eggs. (Example
weight_increase,_a_unit_of_weight_of_egg.definition: 1.85 g feed per 1 g increase body weight). See Feed efficiency. 33

feed_efficiency_(fe).definition: the amount of body weight increase, eggs weight produced, or

dozen_of_eggs_produced_by_a_unit_of_feed.term: dozen of eggs produced by a unit of feed. (Example
dozen_of_eggs_produced_by_a_unit_of_feed.definition: 0.54 g increase body weight per 1 g of feed, which is the same as 1.85 feed conversion ratio). See Feed conversion ratio.

feeder.definition: equipment that supplies feed to birds; operation may be manual, semi-automatic or automatic, including weighing and portioning of the feed.

feed_formula.definition: the listing of ingredients and the percent or weight of each in a mixed feed or diet.

feed_hopper.definition: a semi-automatic feeder in which feed is stored in a hopper or reservoir and flows by gravity into the feed trough.

feeding_trial.definition: a comparison of experimental groups fed different diets.

female_reproductive_system.definition: consists of the ovary, oviduct and cloaca. In most domestic birds, only the left ovary and oviduct are functional.

femur.definition: thigh bone; leg bone that articulates with the hip bone on the proximal end and knee on the distal end.

feral.definition: wild or untamed. Often applied to birds that once were in domestic flocks but are now free-living in the wild.

fertility_or_fertile_eggs.definition: the proportion of eggs in which fertilization has occurred. Usually expressed as a percentage of eggs set.

fertilization.definition: the joining of male and female gametes, i.e., sperm and ovum, to form a zygote or new individual.

fever.definition: an abnormal increase in body temperature due to disease. Compare Hyperthermia.

fibula.definition: the minor bone of the lower leg (drumstick) which is fused with the longer and larger tibia.

filoplumes.definition: a thin, hair-like feather without a vane.

finish.definition: amount of fat under the skin of a meat bird.

finisher_diet.definition: the diet used at the end of the production period for broilers.

first_filial_generation_(f_).definition: progenyfrom mating poultry of two genetic types. 1

fish_meal.definition: fish or fish parts processed into a dry meal product used as a feed ingredient as a source of protein, fat, minerals and vitamins. 34

fistula.definition: a tube, pipe or other artificial opening inserted into the body for experimental or surgical purposes.

flats_(egg).definition: trays with depressions or pockets in which eggs are placed for holding, transport, incubation or marketing.

fledge.definition: having grown and developed enough to leave the nest and fly.

fledgling.definition: a young bird that has just fledged or left the nest.

flight.definition: a flock or group of birds flying together.

flight_feathers_(penniges).definition: feathers on the wings known as primaries and secondaries. Primaries are long feathers on the distal part of the wing, usually 10 in number, having a rigid quill and relatively smooth, flat surface; used in flight but otherwise folded close to the body. Secondaries are on the proximal part of the wing, and are usually shorter than primaries. These feathers have a strong shaft and broad vane or web.

flighty.definition: birds that are excitable and tend to fly when only slightly disturbed.

flocculation.definition: the coming together of coalescing and minute particles in a liquid

flock.definition: a group of birds that feed or move together. In domestication they will normally be of the same type and age, housed together, and managed the same.

flock_mating.definition: mating of a flock of females with males placed in the pen at a ratio of

approximately_1_male.definition: 10 females, depending on breed, age, etc.

floor_eggs.definition: eggs laid on the floor rather than in nest boxes of floor-type laying or breeder houses.

floor_house.definition: cage-free house with litter floor in which manure accumulates in the litter.

floor_layers.definition: hens that lay eggs on the floor. More broadly, hens kept in a house with a large floor area available to them.

floor_space.definition: the amount of space on the floor allotted for each bird.

flukes.definition: parasitic flatworms that attack poultry, either internally or externally. Snails are usually an intermediate host. See Trematode.

foggers.definition: a system using nozzles where water is forced through an extremely small opening at a high rate of speed or pressure (from 300 to > 1000 psi) to create a fine mist. 35 Such systems are used in hatcheries to increase humidity and in both hatcheries and poultry houses for cooling.

fold_unit,_folding_system.definition: a system of housing poultry using a small pen with attached wire mesh enclosure. Moved daily or periodically to fresh pasture or other space.

folic_acid.definition: a water-soluble vitamin essential for the bird. Deficiencies cause poor growth, perosis, anemia and reduced hatchability.

follicle.definition: vascular membrane surrounding an ovum in the ovary. Involved in ovum formation and hormone production.

fomite.definition: a person, animal or physical entity that transports an infective agent from one location to another.

foot_force.definition: pressure on the floor generated by steps of a walking bird; its measurement provides an evaluation of foot and leg health.

foramen.definition: an opening, often through bone, through which nerves, blood vessels, etc. may pass.

forced_draft_incubator.definition: an incubator in which the air is circulated by a fan. See Incubator.

forced_molt.definition: the partial or whole molting of feathers intentionally induced by changes in environment, diet or other means. The physiological process also includes the rejuvenation of the reproductive system to partially restore egg production rate and egg quality thus extending the productive life of the hen.

formalin.definition: a chemical used to produce formaldehyde gas that has been used in fumigating eggs and equipment in hatcheries.

fowl.definition: 1) domestic birds used for food and other economic purposes, including chickens, turkeys, ducks, geese, guinea, quails, pheasants, pigeons, etc. 2) Stewing hen. See Poultry.

fowl_cholera.definition: an infectious poultry disease caused by the bacteria Pasteurella multocida. Mortality can be very high.

fowl_paralysis.definition: a virus disease affecting the legs and wings until the bird eventually cannot stand. Involves the enlargement and derangement of various nerves. See Marek’s disease. Controlled to a large extent by vaccination. 36

fowl_pox.definition: a viral infection causing lesions with scabs on the comb, wattles and around the eyes and face. A “wet” form also causes lesions in the mouth and throat. Primarily controlled by vaccination and sanitation.

fowl_typhoid.definition: a disease caused by the bacteria Salmonella gallinarum. Similar to pullorum but more common in adult birds.

free_choice_feeding.definition: providing feed ingredients in separate feeders and allowing the birds to select the amount of each they may eat. Commercially, it might involve 2 feeders with one containing ground cereal, the other a high protein source, with vitamin and mineral supplements mixed with one of the ingredients.

free_range_management.definition: non-confinement production alternative allowing birds to forage freely (loosely defined by USDA guidelines).

frizzle.definition: a feather that is curved out from the body. A characteristic of the Frizzle breed of chickens.

fronts_(front_quarters).definition: the front half of a ready-to-cook young chicken consisting of the whole breast, both wings and back portion. This item in generally further processed.

fryer.definition: a young meat-type bird that can be cooked in a variety of ways, including frying. See Broiler.

fully_furnished.definition: a term used by fanciers to indicate a mature bird with complete adult plumage.

fumigation.definition: the use of formaldehyde or similarly effective gas to disinfect houses, rooms, equipment, incubators, eggs, etc. Some of the products used are health hazards.

fungus,_fungi_(plural).definition: a large group of plant-like organisms that includes molds, yeasts, mushrooms, mildews, rusts, and smuts, many of which produce toxins. Responsible for many disease conditions in birds.

further_processing.definition: preparation of the carcass beyond the normal processing point of cutting the dressed carcass into portions.

gait_score.definition: evaluation of a bird’s ability to walk. 37

gall_bladder.definition: a membranous sac attached to the liver that acts as a reservoir for bile produced by the liver.

gallinaceous.definition: birds in the order Galliformes that nest on the ground and which include domestic chickens, jungle fowl, pheasants, grouse and others.

gallus.definition: the genus of chickens and jungle fowl. Refers to comb.

galt.definition: gut-associated lymphoid tissue. See Microbial mediated immunodevelopment.

game_birds.definition: birds such as quail, pheasant, chukar, mallard ducks and wild turkeys that are utilized for meat and for hunting. Most are currently grown domestically for release on hunting preserves or for meat.

gamete.definition: a reproductive cell, either sperm or ovum, prior to fertilization. It is haploid, having half the number of chromosomes of autosomal cells.

gangrene.definition: dead tissue in an animal, usually because of poor blood supply.

gapeworms.definition: very small roundworms that infest the trachea. Male and female worms are permanently attached. Intermediate hosts include earthworms and snails but are not necessary for infection.

gastrulation.definition: a stage of early embryonic development in which cells migrate to begin forming specific layers of cells.

gateway_cages.definition: a colony cage system designed to give birds more freedom of movement than in conventional cages.

gene.definition: units occurring at specific points on chromosomes by which inherited characters are transmitted to progeny and which function as determinants of physiological processes. Some may act as on-off switches for other genes.

general_purpose_breed.definition: a breed of chicken that has good egg production and which is large enough with sufficient fleshing to also provide meat, especially the surplus cockerels. They are not efficient enough for commercial stock but are often used in home flocks.

genetics.definition: the area of biological science that deals with heredity and variation in organisms and, when applied, is used to change characteristics of the organism.

genetic_drift.definition: performance characteristics such as egg production or growth rate tend to change from an established level in the absence of intentional selection.

genital_eminence.definition: a small bump on the inner ventral wall of the cloaca that differs slightly between male and female newly hatched chicks and which is used by sexors to differentiate sex of the chicks. 38

genotype.definition: the characteristics of an individual determined by genetic components.

genus.definition: a classification of animals or plants having common distinguishing characteristics; a subdivision of a family and may consist of one or more species.

germ.definition: 1) the living cell (embryo) of the germinal disc (blastoderm) on the surface of the egg yolk. 2) It may also refer to bacteria or to the reproductive center of a plant seed.

germicide.definition: a substance capable of killing disease causing organisms. See Disinfectant.

germinal_disc.definition: the reproductive cell on the surface of the egg yolk underneath the vitelline membrane. The blastodisc, or unfertilized ovum, is a dense white spot whereas the blastoderm, or fertilized ovum, is a white ring at the time of oviposition.

giblets.definition: organs and other parts considered edible including heart, liver, gizzard and neck.

gizzard.definition: the muscular stomach, posterior to the proventriculus, the function of which is to grind food. Under natural conditions it will contain small stones, picked up by the bird, that aid in the grinding process. Also Ventriculus.

gizzard_erosion.definition: the internal wall lining of the gizzard may show hemorrhages and partial loss of the lining due to fungal toxins or nutritional problems.

gland.definition: an organ or group of cells that produce a substance that is used by the body, influences the body or a part of the body, or is excreted from the body.

glandular_stomach.definition: the proventriculus or thick walled organ anterior to the gizzard and posterior to the esophagus that secretes digestive acids. See Proventricullus.

glottis.definition: a slit-like opening into the larynx from the oral cavity that is open for breathing and closed for swallowing.

gobble.definition: the characteristic sound made by a male turkey.

goiter.definition: enlarged thyroid glands, usually due to a deficiency of dietary iodine.

golf_ball_yolks.definition: egg yolks that have a consistency similar to soft clay. These usually result from dietary ingredients containing fatty acids that, when transferred to the yolk, cause the yolk lipids to solidify when the egg is cooled. One example is certain fatty acids found in cottonseed meal.

gonads.definition: the reproductive organs, ovary in females and testes in males, that produce gametes and hormones. 39

gonadotropic_hormones.definition: hormones (follicle stimulating hormone, or FSH, and luteinizing hormone, or LH) produced in the pituitary gland that control processes in the gonads.

goose.definition: 1) long-necked, web-footed, large fowl (waterfowl) of the Anser genus, subfamily Anserinae. There are several domestic breeds and species as well as several wild species. 2) It is also the female of the species.

gossypol.definition: a toxic substance found in unprocessed cottonseed meal that will cause olive green yolks, pink albumen, and decreased hatchability. Heating and oil extraction reduce or destroys gossypol.

gout.definition: swelling in feet or joints resulting from excess uric acid in the blood.

gradeable_nest_runs_(gnr).definition: eggs from a production facility that have had some “checks’ or “dirties” and other obvious undergrades removed and are suitable for grading.

graded_loose.definition: shell eggs that have been washed, sized, and candled for quality and packed in trays, flats or non-carton containers.

grading.definition: eggs and meat bird carcasses are often evaluated and assigned scores or grades that reflect quality of the product.

grain.definition: seeds of cereals that are edible for humans and/or animals. Usually ground to various sized particles for mixing in feeds.

green_or_blue_egg_shells.definition: a greenish color in the egg shell resulting from the presence of the gene for oocyan. This gene occurs in the Araucana breed but may be introduced into any other breed.

green_food.definition: fresh, green plant material used for feedstuff; does not include root feedstuffs.

green_gosling.definition: a young goose commonly used in celebration of Michaelmas (English).

greenhouse_gases.definition: the major gases from poultry productions systems contributing to the global greenhouse effect (CH , N O, and CO ). 4 2 2

green_yolks.definition: may be caused by dietary gossypol or by contamination.

grit.definition: small pieces of stone used by the bird to assist in grinding foodstuffs in the gizzard. Insoluble grit is usually granite or other hard stone. Soluble grit is usually limestone or oyster shell, which may be digested and absorbed as a source of calcium for bone or shell formation. Commercial production systems rarely feed grit. 40

groundnuts.definition: peanuts or earthnuts. The meal can be used as an ingredient and protein source for poultry feeds.

grower_or_growing_birds.definition: birds in the age range between brooding and sexual maturity.

grower_diet.definition: the diet given to growing birds, usually following the starter diet. There may be multiple grower diets that vary in formulation based on differences in nutrient requirements due to age and other factors.

growth_promoter.definition: a feed additive that enhances growth, feed efficiency, or both.

guinea_or_guineafowl.definition: a domestic fowl (Numida meleagris) that is native of Africa and used for meat and eggs.

gular_flutter.definition: fluttering of the throat area to cause movement of air and evaporative cooling without hypocapnia and alkalosis that can result from panting.

gynandromorph.definition: an individual that has both male and female characteristics and contains cells that are genetically male (ZZ) and others that are genetically female (ZW). See also Hermaphrodite.

habituation.definition: reduction or loss of response as a result of repeated stimulation.

hackles.definition: pointed, narrow feathers on the side and back of the neck. These feathers are more rounded in the female.

hairline_crack.definition: very small egg shell cracks not normally visible.

hammer_mill.definition: machine for chopping grains into small particles.

handle.definition: “to handle” is the examination of body characteristics of a bird (handling quality) such as spread of the pubic bones, width of back, depth of body in the visual assessment of the bird’s condition, reproductive potential, etc.

harderian_gland.definition: a small gland located ventral and posteromedial to the eyeball that has a role in the immune system.

hatch.definition: 1) the emergence of young from an egg; 2) young that have emerged from the same group of eggs.

hatchability.definition: 1) of eggs set = the percentage of total eggs of a set that hatch; 2) of fertile eggs = the percentage of fertile eggs of a set that hatch. It may be further defined by counting only the saleable or useable chicks. 41

(as_)hatched.definition: newly hatched chicks that have not been separated according to gender; see Straight-run.

hatcher.definition: type of incubator in which eggs are placed in trays or baskets during the last few days (about 72 hours) of incubation to accommodate the hatching process. Small incubators may have a separate compartment for hatching.

hatchery.definition: a place where chicks or other young fowl are hatched. Modern hatcheries usually include areas for egg traying, egg storage, egg warming, setter incubators, hatcher incubators, chick processing (removal from trays, vaccination, sexing, counting, boxing, loading for transport), and cleaning. A high standard of sanitation is essential.

hatch_position.definition: embryonic position within the egg just before the hatching process begins. In most birds the long axis of the embryo matches the long axis of the egg, the head is in the large end of the egg and bent forward and back toward the body to tuck the beak under the right wing, and the beak is pointed toward the air cell. See Malposition.

hatch_residue.definition: the unhatched eggs, pips, and dead chicks left in the trays after removal of the hatched chicks. Hatchery waste or egg residue.

haugh_units.definition: a measure of egg quality. Eggs are broken onto a level glass pane and the height of the albumen is determined at a standard location. Height values are converted to Haugh Units (H.U.) using a table or formulas that adjust for egg weight. H.U. values range from 0 to 110.

head.definition: the most anterior part of the body that includes the skull and brain, face, eyes, ears, beak, comb, wattles and nostrils.

head_spot.definition: a light colored spot in the down on the head of chicks having sex-linked barred feathers. It can be used for identifying the sex of chicks from Barred Plymouth Rocks and some other breeds and crosses.

heart.definition: the organ that pumps blood throughout the body. It is four-chambered in the bird. The right ventricle moves blood through the lungs for gas exchange whereas the left ventricle moves blood through the remainder of the body. The right ventricle is smaller in the bird in part because the avian lung does not expand and contract, thus it has less variation in resistance to blood flow.

heart_rate.definition: the number of beats per minute, or pulse rate. Heart rate is 200 to 400 beats per minute in the chicken, varying inversely with body size.

heating_degree_day.definition: the difference between the mean daily temperature and the desired temperature. Therefore, with a mean daily temperature of 40°F and a desired temperature of 65°F, heating degree-days would = 25. 42

heat_loss.definition: birds lose heat by evaporative (respiratory and cutaneous) and non- evaporative (conduction, convection and radiation).

heavy_breed.definition: a standard or commercial breed of chicken having large body size. They commonly lay brown eggs and have red ear lobes.

helper_t_cell.definition: a T-cell that assists other T-cells or B-cells in responding to an antigen, or which activates other types of cells, such as macrophages.

hemagglutination_inhibition_(hi)_test.definition: lab test to estimate the amount of antibodies present in a bird against a specific disease.

hematocrit.definition: the percentage of red blood cells in the blood.

hematoma.definition: accumulation of blood caused by a break in a blood vessel.

hemoglobin.definition: an oxygen-carrying red pigment of the red blood cells consisting primarily of protein and iron.

hemorrhage.definition: the leakage of a large amount of blood from a vessel.

hen.definition: a female chicken that is more than one year old. May be applied to a female bird that is sexually mature (lays eggs).

hen_day_egg_production.definition: eggs produced in a given period divided by the number of hens times number of days they were present (eggs/hens x days). Usually expressed as a percentage. It adjusts for hen mortality and is often used in research. It may also be calculated on a daily basis by dividing the number of eggs laid by the number of hens present that day.

hen_feathered.definition: in some breeds of chickens there is no sexual dimorphism in regard to feathering color and feather shape with both female and male having female type feathering (e.g., Sebright bantams).

hen_housed_egg_production.definition: eggs produced in a given period divided by the number of hens in the house at the beginning of the period times the days of the period (eggs/hens started x days). Usually expressed as a percentage. It does not adjust for hen mortality but is a good indicator of profitability.

hen_spectacles_or_lens.definition: spectacles are small plastic devices that attach to the upper beak and block forward vision of the bird. Lens are red colored contact inserts for the eye. 43 Both devices aim to prevent or reduce feather picking, cannibalism, and egg eating by the birds.

hepatic_portal_system.definition: venous blood flow is diverted to the liver before returning to the heart. It must be considered in procedures in which substances are injected into the legs.

heredity.definition: the transmission of characteristics of an individual to its offspring by means of genes.

hermaphrodite.definition: an individual with a mixture of male and female sexual organs; a Gynandromorph.

heterakis_gallinae.definition: small, white roundworms found in the ceca that act as a carrier of the organism that causes Blackhead disease. See Cecal worms and Blackhead.

heterogametic.definition: producing gametes that may contain either male or female chromosomes. The female is the heterogametic sex in birds and some other species whereas in mammals the male is the heterogametic sex.

heterosis.definition: the offspring have a higher level of performance than the parents. It is referred to as hybrid vigor. Parent lines or breeds that, when crossed, produce chicks with heterosis are described as “nicking”.

heterozygous.definition: when a pair of autosomal genes at the same locus differ the individual is heterozygous for that character. Offspring will vary according to which gene they receive, thus, heterozygotes do not breed true.

hibernate.definition: to become dormant, especially in cold weather. Some birds, such as hummingbirds become torpid during the night in a temporary hibernation. See Torpidity and Estivate.

high_rise_house.definition: cage house in which manure accumulates in a lower level storage space that is cleaned yearly.

histology.definition: the microscopic study of body tissue structure.

histomoniasis.definition: a protozoal disease (Blackhead) occurring primarily in turkeys, gamebirds and peafowl caused by Histomonas meleagridis, which is often transmitted by the nematode Heterakis gallinarum.

hock.definition: the joint between the tibia and tarsometatarsus bones (between drumstick and shank).

hock_burns.definition: irritation of the skin of the hock joint due to contact with irritants in the litter.

homeostasis.definition: a tendency to maintain a normalcy and stability in the body. 44

homeotherm.definition: an animal that attempts to maintain constant body temperature in all environmental temperatures. However, some may hibernate, estivate or have temporary torpor. Warm blooded.

homogametic.definition: producing gametes that contain only one type of sex chromosome. In birds the male is homogametic and the female gamete determines the sex of the offspring.

homozygous.definition: when a pair of autosomal genes at the same locus are the same the individual is homozygous for that character. Parents homozygous for a character will breed true for that character.

horizontal_integration.definition: cooperation among members of a segment of an industry (for example, hatcheries).

hormone.definition: a substance produced by a gland or tissue and transported by the blood to another tissue or organ (target) where it activates and/or modulates physiological activities. There are also synthetically produced hormones.

host.definition: an animal that is infected or in some way supports the growth and spread of a micro-organism or parasite.

host_specific.definition: a disease or parasite that is found on or in a single species or closely related species.

housing.definition: buildings in which poultry are kept. They vary from small moveable houses in pastures to very large egg production, broiler or breeder houses that are semi- environmentally controlled with birds on litter, slats or in cages. In some geographical areas they are called barns.

hover.definition: equipment providing heat, insulation and umbrella cover for young chicks during the brooding period.

humerus.definition: the proximal bone of the wing.

humidity.definition: the percentage of water vapor in the air. See Relative humidity.

humoral_immunity.definition: an immune response that involves antibodies secreted by B-cells circulating in body fluids.

hybrid.definition: offspring resulting from the cross of different inbred strains, varieties or breeds. In commercial usage, it refers to crosses developed for specific economic traits and produced on a large commercial scale. The hybrid is often superior to either of the parents.

hydrometer.definition: an instrument used to measure the specific gravity of liquids. 45

hygrometer.definition: an instrument that measures the absolute or relative amount of moisture in the air.

hypercapnia.definition: unusually high levels of carbon dioxide in the blood.

hyperplasia.definition: an abnormal increase in the number of cells of a tissue or organ.

hyperthermia.definition: an increase in body temperature above normal; it can be due to a normal physiological process and in response to the environment.

hypertrophy.definition: the increase in volume of tissue by the enlargement of the cells present.

hypocapnia.definition: unusually low levels of carbon dioxide in the blood.

hypoplasia.definition: organ or tissue below normal size.

hyporachis.definition: a small secondary feather attached to the shaft of a large feather.

hypothalamus.definition: a gland located near the base of the brain which serves as a photoreceptor, produces gonadotropin releasing hormone (GnRH), and acts in many other roles.

hypotrophy.definition: degeneration or loss of function of an organ or tissue.

hysteria.definition: a condition of hyperexcitement in a flock, occurring in episodes and often lasting for long periods. Birds run aimlessly, pile on one another, receive injuries from toe nails, and feed consumption decreases, growth or egg production decline.

ice_packed.definition: a form of refrigeration in which processed raw products are packed in containers and then covered with shaved or crushed ice manufactured from water, or dry ice manufactured from carbon dioxide (CO2).

ileum.definition: the posterior portion of the small intestine, from Meckel’s diverticulum to the large intestine/cecal junction. The anatomy in the bird is not as distinctive as in some species.

ilium.definition: the dorsal or upper portion of the pelvic girdle. It is the large bone in which the femur articulates.

imbalanced.definition: refers to a dietary situation in which some necessary constituents are not in the proper amount or ratio to provide optimum nutrition. 46

immunity.definition: resistance or protection against a particular disease or infection.

immunity,_active_or_acquired.definition: immunity induced through response to infection with a pathogen or through vaccination. Response is to a specific antigen using humoral (B, or bursa-derived, lymphocytes) and cell-mediated (T, or thymus-derived, lymphocytes) and includes memory development to that antigen.

immunity,_innate.definition: immunity that is a rapidly induced broad response to infectious microbes using phylogenetically encoded receptors (pattern recognition receptors).

immunity,_passive.definition: immunity that occurs without infection or vaccination. One source of passive immunity is maternal antibodies passed through the egg to the chick.

immunize.definition: to produce immunity, usually by inoculation.

impaction.definition: blockage of an organ such as crop, gizzard, or oviduct.

impingent_air_jet.definition: air traveling along a smooth surface, such as a ceiling or side wall. Such air jets will travel approximately 25% further than a similar air jet in open space.

imprint.definition: the behavior and memory of a young bird is fixated on another bird, animal or object in such a manner that it elicits certain responses in later life.

inanition.definition: condition resulting from lack of food or lack of ability to assimilate it.

inbreeding.definition: the mating of closely related birds, usually for several generations.

inclusion_body_hepatitis.definition: an acute infectious disease of the liver caused by an adenovirus.

incross.definition: offspring resulting from the mating of inbred lines of the same breed.

incrossbred.definition: offspring resulting from the mating of inbred lines of different breeds.

incubation.definition: the process by which eggs are placed in an appropriate environment for development of the embryo. One or both of the parents sit on eggs to naturally incubate eggs. Artificial incubation involves providing cabinets in which eggs are exposed to appropriately controlled temperature, humidity, air exchange and movement, egg orientation and turning frequency.

incubation_position.definition: under commercial conditions eggs of most poultry are incubated with the large end up and turned at one hour intervals around the short axis to approximately 45 degree angles until a few days before hatching. Eggs from all poultry and especially those with large eggs, such as the goose, may be incubated horizontally and turned around the long axis. Most eggs in natural nests will be incubated horizontally.

incubation_temperature.definition: the normal incubation temperature is approximately 99.5°F (37.5°C) but the ideal temperature varies with age of embryo and its heat production, 47 humidity, species, and strain. Single stage and multistage incubators will have different ideal temperatures.

incubation_time,_hatch_time.definition: 1) the time (days or hours) required for the embryo to fully develop from the time of setting in the incubator to emergence from the egg. It usually does not include the development time (about 20 hours) while in the hen’s oviduct.

approximate_incubation_times_(days)_for_.term: Approximate incubation times (days) for common species are
approximate_incubation_times_(days)_for_.definition: chicken, 20-21; turkey, 26- 28; duck, 26-28; muscovy duck, 35-37; geese, 30-35; pigeon, 17-19; bobwhite quail, 23- 24; coturnix quail, 16-17; pheasant, 23-24; ostrich, 40-42. 2) Incubation period may also refer to the time between exposure to a pathogen and the onset of clinical signs.

incubator.definition: the cabinet or machine in which eggs are placed for development and hatching. The setter accommodates the eggs during the major portion of incubation (the first 18 days in chickens), whereas the hatcher accommodates the eggs during the hatching process (the last 3 days of incubation). Incubators may be Single stage or Multistage and forced draft or still air.

indeterminate_layer.definition: the number of eggs per clutch is not strictly pre-set and the number of eggs may vary with weather, food supply, competition, etc. Birds such as chickens, which will continue to lay an indefinite number of eggs if eggs are removed from the nest, are indeterminate layers. See Determinate layer.

inedible_eggs.definition: eggs that are not allowed for human consumption. They are segregated and typically sold to pet food companies.

infection.definition: invasion of the body or some part of the body by a pathogen.

infectious_bronchitis.definition: a common, serious, very infectious viral disease of poultry. May cause high mortality, especially in young birds. Layers may have severe drop in egg production and rough, thin, ridged, or mis-shapen egg shells. Vaccines are available.

infectious_bursal_disease.definition: an immune system disease of the young chicken that is caused by a virus. Historically called Gumboro Disease. The disease causes a decreased immunity and a decreased ability to respond to vaccination or infection. Vaccines are available.

inferior_umbilicus.definition: opening in the tip of the feather quill.

infertile.definition: an egg that has not been fertilized; there has been no union of sperm and ovum.

inflammation.definition: a reaction of some part of the body to injury, irritation, infection or some other insult that causes pain, swelling, redness, increased temperature or even loss of function. 48

influenza.definition: avian influenza is a viral disease of the respiratory system. Several types of the virus are known; most have low virulence, however, one or more type causes severe mortality.

infra_red_heater.definition: brooders or heaters utilizing infra-red radiation as the heat source. The amount of visible light emitted varies with the type.

infundibulum.definition: the most anterior section of the oviduct. Funnel shaped and open to receive or engulf the ovulated ovum. Becomes very active at the time of ovulation. It is the site of fertilization. See Oviduct.

ingest.definition: to take food into the mouth; to eat.

inhibiting_gene.definition: a gene that inhibits, suppresses or prevents expression of another gene.

injection.definition: the introduction of an organism or substance into the body by the following

common_routes.definition: subcutaneous (sub-Q) or under the skin; intramuscular (I.M.) or into a muscle; intraperitoneal (I.P.) or into the body cavity; and intravenous (I.V.) or into a vein.

in_line_egg_production.definition: the arrangement of egg conveyor and processing equipment into one or more straight lines to facilitate the movement of shell eggs directly from the laying house(s) to the grading and packing or further processing areas.

inner_thin.definition: a layer of thin albumen between the chaliziferous and thick albumen layers in the egg. See Albumen.

insectivorous.definition: eating insects and small arthropods as the primary food.

insemination.definition: placement of semen from the male into the oviduct of the female. Artificial insemination is essential in commercial turkeys and can be used in some breeds of chickens and other species to improve fertility. It is often used in research studies of reproduction and in some breeding programs. Artificial insemination is labor intensive.

insulation.definition: a material that minimizes the transfer of heat into or from a structure, machine or cabinet. To accomplish this efficiently the material must contain a large number of small, isolated dead air spaces. Such materials will reduce heat transfer by radiation, convection and conduction. Feathers and fat layers provide insulation for the bird’s body.

integrator.definition: (Vertical integration) coordination of various levels of producing, processing and distributing under one decision making unit, generally through direct ownership of the different stages or through contracts. A vertically integrated firm will consist of breeder flocks, hatcheries, feed milling and delivery, growout units, processing plants, further processing plants, and delivery to buyers. 49

integument.definition: the external body covering including the skin, feathers, beak, comb, wattles, scales and nails.

intensity.definition: 1) as applied to egg production, it is the rate of lay over a given period of time. 2) As applied to lighting, it is the amount of light per unit area.

intensive_system.definition: maintenance of birds entirely in buildings in high concentrations consistent with welfare and production.

intermediate_host.definition: some parasites of birds spend a stage of their life in another animal such as snails or earthworms, which are the intermediate host.

intermittent_lighting.definition: a lighting program in which the “light period” is broken into multiple short periods of light and dark. Interrupted lighting. Also called Biomittent.

internal_layer.definition: at ovulation the ovum (yolk) is not engulfed by the infundibulum but remains in the body cavity. Small numbers of these yolks can be absorbed but if large numbers remain in the cavity yolk residue may accumulate. Some affected birds may develop a “penquin” posture. See Egg yolk peritonitis.

internal_parasites.definition: organisms that live within the body of the bird (host). It commonly refers to worms or protozoa.

intestines,_intestinal_tract.definition: organs involved with eating, digesting and excreting

foodstuffs._these_organs_in_order_are.term: foodstuffs. These organs in order are
foodstuffs._these_organs_in_order_are.definition: mouth, esophagus with crop, proventriculus, ventriculus or gizzard, duodenum, jejunum, ileum, ceca, large intestine, and cloaca.

in_vitro.definition: “in glass”; occurring outside of the living animal.

in_vivo.definition: “in living”; occurring within the living animal.

iris.definition: the round, muscular, pigmented membrane around the pupil of the eye that changes the size of the pupil to regulate the amount of light entering the eye.

ischium.definition: the large posterior portion of the pelvic girdle or hip.

isolation.definition: keeping a bird or flock of birds in a separate location from other birds taking all precautions to prevent transfer of diseases or parasites to or from the flock. It is part of the biosecurity program.

isthmus.definition: the narrow, thin walled portion of the oviduct in which the shell or egg membranes are formed around the albumen. It is located between the magnum and shell gland. See Oviduct.

jejunum.definition: portion of the small intestine from the duodenum to the ileum, the junction of which is marked by Meckel’s diverticulum in most birds.

joint.definition: the junction between two bones, especially where bones articulate. 50

joule.definition: a unit of energy or heat. One joule = 0.24 calorie (approximately).

jugular_vein.definition: carries blood returning from the head and neck.

kafir_or_kafir_corn.definition: a grain sorghum grown for grain and fodder.

keel.definition: the large projection of the sternum or breastbone to which the large flight muscles of the breast are attached. Flightless birds (e.g., ostrich) do not have a keel.

keratin.definition: a protein that forms much of the structure of feathers, leg scales, toe nails, and beak of birds. It has a high sulfur content due to the amino acid cystine.

kidneys.definition: paired organs of the urinary system that are attached to the dorsal wall of the body cavity. They remove waste products from the blood by filtration and active transport. They also function in acid-base balance, mineral absorption and reabsorption, and water balance.

killing_cone.definition: an open-ended, hanging, metal cone in which birds can be placed with head extended outside the small end allowing the throat cut in slaughtering. Used in home or small processing units.

knee.definition: the joint between the upper leg (thigh) and lower leg (drumstick).

knob.definition: 1) the horny bulge on the upper bill of Chinese and African geese; 2) the bulge in the skull of crested birds.

kosher_birds.definition: those processed and sold in accordance with Jewish dietary laws or customs.

lacing.definition: a different colored edging around a feather.

lagoon_system.definition: a method of treating manure from caged layers in which the manure is placed in a large pond of water and allowed to be digested by bacteria, usually anaerobic. Some systems grow fish in the pond.

lamella.definition: the tooth-like serrations of the inner edges of the bill of ducks and geese.

large_intestine.definition: a short portion of the intestine extending from the ileocecal junction to the cloaca, functioning primarily in water absorption. The large intestine of some birds, e.g., ostriches, is very large and appears to function in the digestion of fiber.

laryngotracheitis.definition: a viral disease of the upper respiratory tract. Severe mortality can be prevented by vaccination. 51

larynx.definition: the anterior end of the trachea functioning to prevent food and water from entering the trachea during swallowing. It is not involved in vocalization.

late_hatch.definition: chicks that hatch later than is normal for that species, breed, or strain and age of breeder. These chicks are often less viable than normal.

latent.definition: present but unseen; hidden, inactive or undeveloped.

latent_heat.definition: heat lost through the process of evaporation. See Evaporative heat loss.

lateral.definition: refers to the side or toward the side.

layer.definition: a sexually mature female producing eggs. In common usage, the type of bird producing eggs for consumption.

layer_cycle.definition: the period of the layer’s life from onset of lay until cessation of lay and a natural molt. The cycle may be shortened for economic purposes in commercial flocks.

l.d._50.definition: a lethal dose to one half of individuals treated.

leaker.definition: an egg that has a crack or break in the shell and shell membranes to the extent that the egg contents are exposed or are exuding or free to exude from the shell.

leg.definition: the limb on which the bird walks: thigh, drumstick and shank.

leg_band.definition: bands of plastic or metal placed around the bird’s leg as a means of identification. It may be a simple color code or it may have a number or bar-code.

leghorn.definition: a breed of chicken of the Mediterrean Class that has been used extensively as a base breed for egg production purposes. It produces a white-shelled egg.

leg_quarters.definition: the rear portion of a ready-to-cook young chicken consisting of the drumsticks, thighs and back portion. This item is marketed at retail or further processed.

legume.definition: any of thousands of plant species that have seed pods that split along both sides when ripe. Some of the more common legumes are beans, lentils, peas, and soybeans. Legumes have the unique ability to obtain much or all of their nitrogen requirements from symbiotic nitrogen fixation.

lesion.definition: abnormal tissue caused by injury, disease, parasite, etc.

lethal_gene.definition: a genetic condition that results in abnormal development and death of the embryo. In some cases the embryo may survive beyond hatching but then die, either directly due to the condition or indirectly due to blindness or other conditions that prevent normal activities (facultative or contingent). 52

leucosis.definition: a viral disease of birds causing enlargement of the liver, spleen and kidneys as the bird grows and matures. Partially prevented by vaccination. The complex of diseases include Marek’s disease, Lymphoid leucosis, osteolpetrosis, erythroblastosis, and reticuloendotheliosis.

leukocyte.definition: a type of white blood cell that is involved in the immune system. Some (macrophage) engulf and destroy infectious agents and cellular debris.

life_cycle.definition: a series of developmental stages through which worms, insects, protozoa and other organisms progress during their complete life.

ligament.definition: strong connective tissue holding bones together or holding organs in place.

light_breed.definition: breeds of chickens, such as Leghorns, that generally have characteristics such as small body size, higher metabolic rate, non-broodiness, and high rate of egg production.

lighting.definition: for a detailed glossary of lighting terminology see Lewis and Perry, 1990, Br.

light_schedule_or_pattern.definition: the hours of light and dark (L:D) to which birds are subjected each 24-hour period, including natural and artificial light, intensity, light color, and changes in light.

light_stimulation.definition: the use of light to stimulate the hypothalamus, pituitary and pineal glands resulting in stimulation of the reproductive system and other effects.

limberneck.definition: a condition caused by botulism poisoning. See Botulism.

line_breeding.definition: a system of inbreeding emphasizing use of descendants from a specific ancestor or group of ancestors.

lipid.definition: a group of chemicals including oils, fats, waxes and similar substances, many of which are constituents of cells and necessary in the diet.

liquid_egg.definition: contents of egg (albumen, yolk, or both) that have been removed and handled in bulk.

litter.definition: materials used on the floor of poultry houses. Common litter materials are wood shavings, sawdust, rice hulls, peanut hulls, chopped straw and shredded paper. See Deep litter and Bedding.

litter_amendments.definition: chemicals applied to poultry litter to alter pH, NH volatilization, 3 moisture, microbial growth and other characteristics. 53

livability.definition: usually expressed as the percent of birds living to a specified age.

liver.definition: the large brown organ that functions to assimilate nutrients that are digested, produce various products of metabolism, detoxify toxins, remove metabolic wastes, secrete bile, and other functions.

lobe.definition: fold(s) of skin that hang from the abdomen of some breeds of geese.

long_day.definition: a daylength sufficiently long to induce hormone release and gonadal growth.

loose_eggs.definition: eggs packed in trays, flats, or non-carton containers that have not been sized and candled for quality.

lopped_comb.definition: a comb falling to one side; normal for most hens with single combs.

louver(s).definition: a window or opening having a series of sloping slats of glass, plastic, wood, metal or other material that are movable and admit light and/or air but prevent backflow of air or rain. May be located on the inside or outside of ventilation fans, open and close by gravity or motorization, to prevent the flow of air through the fan when it is not operating.

lumen.definition: 1) measure of illumination. The light emitted by a point-source of 1 candle power; 1 lumen = 0.001496 watt. See Lux and Footcandle. 2) The cavity within a duct or organ.

lungs.definition: paired, non-elastic organs in the thorax with the function of gas exchange. Air sacs push air through a complex air capillary system where gas exchange occurs. It is a flow-through system with no blind pouches in the lungs.

lux.definition: measure of illumination. One lux = 1 lumen per m2 = 0.0929 footcandle; 1 footcandle = 10.76 lux = 1 lumen per ft2. See Lumen and Footcandle.

lymphatic_system.definition: a network of small vessels that collect the watery fluid found in intercellular spaces. Includes lymph nodes that are structures associated with the lymph vessels and which produce lymphocytes and function as part of the immune system.

lymphocyte.definition: a type of white blood cell derived from the thymus or bursa of Fabricius that functions in the immune system.

lymphokine.definition: a substance produced by T-cells that have been stimulated by an antigen. It may be involved in cell-mediated immunity, activation of macrophages or influencing the amount of antibody production.

lysine.definition: an essential amino acid that is often added to the diet in synthesized form.

lysozyme.definition: a protein in egg albumen; it lyses some bacteria. 54

macrophage.definition: a phagocytic tissue cell of the reticuloendothelial system that is involved in protection of the body against infection and toxins. They may become mobile when stimulated by immune reactions, microbial products or inflammation. They may interact with lymphocytes in antibody production.

magnum.definition: the longest portion of the avian oviduct, posterior to the infundibulum and anterior to the isthmus. Its primary function is secretion of the egg albumen. See Oviduct.

main_tail_feathers.definition: stiff, long and straight feathers of the tail. Rectrices.

male_reproductive_system.definition: consists of paired testes, epididymi, ductus deferens, phallus and accessory glands. The accessory glands are the paracloacal vascular bodies, dorsal proctodeal gland, and lymphatic folds, all of which are associated with the cloaca.

malformation.definition: embryos with abnormalities ranging from minor to severe. There are numerous causes for malformations.

malposition.definition: embryonic positions in the egg that are not normal for that specific stage of development and for that species. Some are fatal, e.g. head under left wing, whereas others such as beak over right wing may be normal variants. A common malposition is head in the small end of the egg, commonly caused by incubating the egg with the small end up. See Hatch position.

mammillary_layer.definition: the inner egg shell layer that is attached to the outer egg membrane. Its inner surface knobs are amorphous in nature.

manometer.definition: an instrument used to determine liquid or gas pressure; used to measure the difference between inside house and outside atmospheric pressure, usually expressed in inches of water in a water column.

manure_belt_house.definition: cage house in which manure is caught on a belt from which it is removed daily.

marek’s_disease.definition: a neoplastic disease affecting lymphocytes, causing skin lesions and tumors, and affecting the neural tissue causing paralysis. Vaccination of 18-day embryos or chicks at hatching provides protection. Viruses are the causative agents. See Leucosis.

mash.definition: feed ingredients ground into small particles and mixed to provide a complete diet.

mate.definition: the pairing of male and female for reproduction. 55

maternal_antibodies.definition: antibodies of the hen that are transferred to the chick through the egg yolk.

mating_ratio.definition: the number of females mated to one male. It varies with age, breed and species. The common ratio in commercial chickens is 1 male to 9 to 12 females.

maturity.definition: the female is considered to be sexually mature at the age when the first egg is laid. The male is mature when sufficient sperm are produced to result in a fertile mating. In some cases it refers to the age at which body growth plateaus.

meat_bird.definition: commonly refers to broilers or the type of birds used for broilers.

meat_meal.definition: a feed ingredient produced by cooking, drying and grinding animal products not used for human consumption. It is usually high in protein. Meat meal is a possible mode of transmission of prions related to mad cow disease as well as bacterial organisms.

meat_and_bone_meal.definition: similar to meat meal except it contains some ground bone and therefore has a higher level of calcium and phosphorus.

meat_spots.definition: structures found in egg albumen, usually by candling. They are usually small bits of egg shell cuticle, oviductal or ovarian tissue, or degenerated blood.

mechanical_feeder.definition: motorized, power driven feeding equipment that distributes feed from a large feed hopper to a long trough or a series of hanging feeders. They may be time controlled and include scales for weighing the feed.

mechanical_ventilation.definition: the use of fans to ventilate poultry houses.

mechanically_separated.definition: the manufacturing of poultry products in a paste-like form with the consistency of cake batter. Various poultry items (backs, rib cages, carcass shell, etc) are put through a de-boning machine. This machine operates on the differing resistance of bone and tissue pushed under high pressure through small holes to separate the bone from the edible paste-like product.

meckel’s_diverticulum.definition: the remnant of the embryonic yolk sac attachment to the small intestine. It is used as a marker indicating the end of the jejunum and start of the ileum.

meconium.definition: the greenish fecal material forming the first bowel movement of the newly hatched chick.

medial.definition: toward the middle or midline of the body.

mediterranean_breeds.definition: a group or class of chickens that includes Leghorns and Minorcas. They are usually small, non-broody, high egg-producing, active, and lay white shelled eggs. 56

medullary_bone.definition: bone deposition primarily in the medullary (hollow center) of long bones of the female bird in active egg production that is stimulated by estrogen and androgen. It is very dynamic, being removed for shell deposition and replaced before the next shell is formed.

meiosis.definition: cell division in which the number of chromosomes is changed from diploid of somatic cells to the haploid of gametes.

melanin.definition: a protein pigment that provides color to the feathers, leg skin and beak. The color is usually black, blue or slate but may also be red or brown.

mesentery.definition: connective tissue or membranes that support the digestive system and some other organs, attaching them to the inner body wall or other organs.

mesoderm.definition: the middle layer of embryonic cells that develop into specialized tissues or organs such as skeleton, digestive system, reproductive system and blood.

metabolism.definition: the chemical and physiological processes in the body such as food digestion, breaking down of some substances (catabolism) and building other substances (anabolism).

metabolizable_energy_(me).definition: the total energy consumed by the bird minus the energy excreted in the urine and feces. Digestible energy is the energy assimilated or absorbed by the bird for its physiological use. Existence energy (EE) is ME minus energy used for growth, feathers, reproduction and fat deposition, which is productive energy (PE).

metacarpus.definition: bones of the wing distal to the radius and ulna and to which phalanges are attached.

metamorphosis.definition: change in shape, structure or function resulting from development.

metatarsus.definition: the bone of the leg referred to as shank and to which the phalanges (toes) are attached.

methionine.definition: an essential amino acid containing sulphur that is an important part of the structure of proteins such as those in feathers, beak and scales. It is usually considered to be the first limiting amino acid and is commonly supplemented into diets.

microbially_mediated_immunodevelopment.definition: the antigenic effect of intestinal bacteria on the development of gut associated lymphoid tissue (GALT), Peyer’s patches and other immunological activities of the gut. 57

microclimate.definition: in relation to poultry it is the environment immediately surrounding the animal. Compared to mesoclimate (in the house) and macroclimate (outside the house).

microingredient.definition: components of the diet that are included in minute amounts (normally vitamins and minerals other than calcium and phosphorus).

micromelia.definition: an embryonic abnormality characterized by dwarfing and shortened bones of the legs and wings. It is usually lethal.

microphthalmia.definition: an embryonic abnormality in which one or both eyes will be very small or missing.

microswitch.definition: a small electrical contact used in controls of incubators and other equipment.

middlings.definition: a byproduct of wheat milled for flour that comes from the layer of the kernel under the outer husks. It is a common feed ingredient.

millers_offals.definition: discarded parts of milled grain, such as middlings, bran and wheatings, that can be used in animal feeds.

milk,_dried_skimmed.definition: a dried milk product that can be incorporated into poultry feeds.

millet.definition: a small grain (e.g., pearl millet) used as a feed ingredient.

milo.definition: grain sorghum used in diets in place of maize.

minerals.definition: the inorganic elements utilized by the bird in metabolism. Some, such as calcium and phosphorus, are required in relatively large amounts, whereas others, such as iodine, zinc and cobalt, are required in very small amounts. Some may be added to the diet as organic complexes.

minimally_processed.definition: a process which does not fundamentally alter the raw meat product (USDA definition).

molasses.definition: a thick, dark syrup produced during sugar refining or from sorghum or other sources that can be used as a feed ingredient.

molt.definition: the casting off of old feathers followed by their re-growth. In natural environmental conditions this occurs seasonally and is associated with atrophy of the reproductive system. In poultry management systems the molt and associated atrophy and re-growth (recrudescence) of the reproductive system are induced or “forced” by manipulation of the lighting system and nutrition to result in rejuvenation of egg production and egg quality. 58

mongrel.definition: mixed-breed bird resulting from indiscriminate matings.

moniliasis_or_candidiasis.definition: an upper digestive tract fungus infection (thrush), often caused by Candida, and more common in turkeys.

monochromatic.definition: light with one color, or a very narrow range of wavelengths.

morbidity.definition: the number or percentage of a flock that is affected by disease or parasitism.

morphogenesis.definition: structural changes that occur during the development of an organ, tissue, or individual.

morphology.definition: the study of form and structure of living organisms.

mortality.definition: the birds that die, often expressed as a percentage. Death rate as opposed to Livability.

mottling.definition: 1) in feathers it refers to dark feathers with some of them having a white tip, as in the Anconas breed (compare to Spangling). 2) In eggs the yolk is discolored with splotches of green or other abnormal colors.

mucosa_or_mucous_membrane.definition: the lining membrane of body cavities and canals, such as digestive and respiratory systems, that connect with the external air.

mufa.definition: monounsaturated fatty acids. See also PUFA.

muff.definition: a tuft of feathers on the sides of the head of some breeds, e.g., Houdans.

mule_duck.definition: the cross between a Muscovy and another domestic duck for use for meat purposes. The cross is sterile. See Muscovy.

multi_age_farm.definition: a farm with more than one age-group of chickens.

multiphase_feeding.definition: altering dietary composition to meet anticipated nutrient requirements as they change with age, productions or conditions.

multiplier_farm.definition: a farm that produces hatching eggs from breeder stock supplied by a breeding company and which results in chicks that are used commercially as broiler chicks or layers.

multi_stage_incubation.definition: incubation system or incubator having two or more ages of embryos in each machine. See Incubator and Single stage incubation.

muscovy.definition: a type of domestic duck (Cairina moschata) having crest, red wattles and horizontal carriage and originating in South America. They make a wheezing sound rather that a quack. Can be crossed with other domestic ducks for meat purposes but the cross is sterile (a mule). 59

mushy_chick_disease_or_omphalitis.definition: an abdominal or navel infection of chicks acquired during the hatching process. Controlled by strict sanitation in the hatchery, incubators and hatchers.

mutation.definition: a sudden permanent variation in an inherited character of an animal.

mycoplasmosis.definition: diseases caused by various types of Mycoplasma, which are organisms smaller than bacteria and larger than viruses and that lack a cell wall. Mycoplasma gallisepticum, M. synoviae and M. meleagridis are the most common and are egg transmitted. Controlled mostly by eradication and prevention.

mycosis.definition: a disease caused by a fungus.

mycotoxicosis.definition: effects due to mold toxins from one or more mold species. Common toxins are aflatoxin, ochratoxin and T-2 toxin.

myoglobin.definition: an iron-containing protein, similar to hemoglobin, that is found in muscle and influencing muscle color as well as supplying oxygen.

nares.definition: the external opening of the nostrils.

natural.definition: a product containing no artificial ingredients or added color and is only minimally processed (USDA definition).

naturally_raised.definition: chicks or other animals that received no growth promotants or antibiotics (except ionophores), and were fed no animal byproducts.

natural_ventilation.definition: air circulation is provided by opening poultry house doors, windows, or curtains allowing the wind to draw air through the house.

navel.definition: the scar indicating where the umbilical cord containing the blood vessels to embryonic membranes passed through the body wall. The condition of the navel of the newly hatched chick is used as an indication of the quality and general health of the chick. See Umbilicus.

necropsy.definition: examination of a dead body; a post-mortem examination or autopsy.

necrosis.definition: the death and decay of cells in a specific part of the body of a living animal.

necrotic_enteritis.definition: a type of enteritis caused by the organism Clostridium perfringens producing necrosis of the epithelial lining of the small intestine and resulting in death.

nematode.definition: roundworms that are usually unsegmented; include ascarids, gape worms, gizzard worms, capillaria and heterakis that parasitize poultry.

neoplasm.definition: abnormal growth of tissue, such as a tumor. 60

nephritis.definition: acute or chronic disease of the kidneys, including inflammation and degeneration.

nest.definition: in nature it is a place selected or a structure built by birds to lay their eggs and protect their young. Commercial poultry are provided nest structures with padding in which the hens may lay their eggs.

nest_egg.definition: an artificial egg placed in a nest to entice hens to lay eggs there.

nesting_behavior.definition: in domestic chickens this involves a period of investigating nests, selection of a nest, oviposition, exit from the nest, often followed by cackling for a short time.

nestling.definition: a young bird still in the nest.

nest_run_eggs.definition: eggs that are packed as they come from the production facilities without having been washed, sized, and candled for quality, except that some checks and dirties and other obvious undergrads have been removed.

net_energy.definition: metabolizable energy minus the energy used during digestion.

newcastle_disease.definition: a respiratory and nervous system disease caused by various strains of a paramyxovirus. Commercial birds are vaccinated multiple times and with different virus strains for prevention of the disease.

new_york_dressed.definition: a processing method in which a fresh plucked chicken carcass is offered for sale without evisceration and refrigeration.

niacin,_nicotinamide_or_nicotinic_acid.definition: a vitamin of the B complex type. A deficiency may cause hock and leg problems, diarrhea, and inflammation in the mouth.

nictitating_membrane.definition: a transparent third eyelid in birds that blinks to keep the eye clean and moist. The upper and lower eyelids remain open when the bird is awake. See Eyelids.

nidicolous.definition: birds that stay in the nest for some time after hatching. See Altricial, Precocial, and Nidifugous.

nidifugous.definition: birds that leave the nest immediately after hatching. See Precocial, Altricial, and Nidicolous. 61

nits.definition: the eggs of lice in the form of clusters of small white spheres at the base of feathers.

nitrogen_free_extract.definition: carbohydrates in the feed utilizable by poultry. Does not include indigestible carbohydrates contained in crude fiber.

nocturnal.definition: refers to the dark period or night; the period between the light/dark and dark/light interfaces.

non_phytate_phosphorus.definition: P not bound to an organic molecule. Inorganic P.

noodling.definition: force-feeding geese with noodles or other feedstuffs to produce pate de foie gras, a product of fattened goose livers. See Cramming.

northern_fowl_mite.definition: an arachnid parasite, very small, that lives on the bird and often is found in higher concentrations among the feathers of the abdominal area. It lives on the blood of the bird.

nose_or_nostril.definition: the external opening of the respiratory system and the organ of smell.

nsp.definition: non-starch polysaccharide; a component of ingredients that can affect digestion and may be a concern in feed formulation.

nuptial_plumage.definition: plumage of the male just before and during the breeding season.

nutritional_encephalomalacia.definition: “crazy chick disease” caused by a vitamin E deficiency.

oats.definition: a cereal grain, relatively high in fiber, that is used in some types of diets, e.g., molting diets.

offal.definition: the waste material from poultry processing, excluding feathers, that is useful as a feed ingredient when cooked and prepared as a meal.

olfaction.definition: the sense of smell; a chemically based sense.

olfactory_organ.definition: an organ involved in the sense of smell, usually the internal cellular lining of the nostrils.

olive_yolks.definition: greenish color in yolk often caused by feeding cottonseed meal.

omega_3_fatty_acids.definition: examples are linolenic, docosahexenoic, docosapentenoic, and eicosapentenoic that have health promoting effects and are used to produce designer eggs.

omnivorous.definition: eating both animal and vegetable foods. Eating anything. 62

omphalitis_or_mushy_chick_disease.definition: navel and abdominal infection in the young chick. Prevented by strict sanitation in the hatchery and breeder farm.

ontogeny.definition: the life cycle of an individual

oocyan.definition: the pigment in some green- and blue-shelled eggs.

oocyst.definition: the starting and ending stage of the life cycle of coccidia. An encapsulated form that is very resistant to the environment.

oocyte.definition: an ovum that has not begun the growth and maturation process.

oogenesis.definition: the process of formation of ova in the ovary.

organic_acids.definition: acids that are produced by plants, animals or microorganisms that have antimicrobial activity (e.g., citric acid, fumaric acid, lactic acid, and formic acid).

organic_production.definition: production of poultry in living conditions that facilitate natural behavior and provide outdoor access, use preventative health management with no antibiotics or drugs, fed certified organic feed (feed ingredients and pasture are produced without synthetic fertilizers and pesticides), grown according to organic plan, and entire operation inspected by auditors.

organoleptic.definition: involving senses such as taste, smell or sight.

orientation.definition: positioning of the long axis of the embryo in respect to the long axis of the egg.

orifice.definition: 1) the opening of an organ or body cavity. 2) With mechanical ventilation, the most restrictive area of the air inlet or the circular area in which the fan operates.

ornamental_breed.definition: a type of bird bred for appearance and show rather than for economic traits.

ornithosis.definition: a viral respiratory disease of birds that can be transmitted to man.

orts.definition: fragments of feed remaining in feeder.

osmoreceptor.definition: cells or tissue that respond to the concentration of sodium or other cations that affect osmotic concentration.

ossification.definition: the process of bone formation, usually changing from cartilage.

ostrich.definition: the largest living bird (Struthio camelus), flightless, native of Africa and Near East, that is used commercially for meat and feathers. Feet have only 2 toes.

outcross.definition: mating birds of one inbred strain to those of another strain that is unrelated, although often of the same breed.

outer_thin.definition: a thin layer of albumen around the equatorial region of the egg between the thick albumen and shell membranes. See Albumen.

ovalbumin.definition: the major protein in egg albumen; it contains an enzyme inhibitor and will bind some minerals.

ovary.definition: female gonad or reproductive organ that produces reproductive cells (ova) and secretes hormones such as estrogen. In most domestic birds only the left ovary is functional. During egg production a few large follicles of graded size and numerous very small follicles are present.

overhead_expenses.definition: business charges that occur, such as management and building maintenance expenses, even when the business is idle. Also known as fixed expenses or costs.

oviduct.definition: a tubular organ of the female reproductive system. The anterior end is attached to the body wall near the ovary and the posterior end terminates at the cloaca. It functions to pick up the ovulated ovum (by the infundibulum) and to deposit albumen (by the magnum), egg membranes (by the isthmus) and egg shell (by the shell gland) around the ovum. The vagina functions in sperm storage and in the oviposition or laying of the egg. Most eggs will move through the oviduct small end first then rotate into the vagina with large end first for oviposition. In most domestic birds the right oviduct is very small and non-functional.

oviparous.definition: type of animals producing eggs that hatch after oviposition, outside of the female body, e.g., birds. See Viviparous and Ovoviviparous.

oviposition.definition: to deposit or lay an egg. Extrusion of the egg from the body, usually large end first.

ovoflavoprotein.definition: a protein in egg albumen; it binds riboflavin.

ovoglobulin_g_and_g.definition: proteins in egg albumen; they have good foaming 2 3 characteristics.

ovomacroglobulin.definition: a protein in egg albumen; it has antigenic effects.

ovomucin.definition: a protein in egg albumen; it inhibits viral hemaglutination.

ovomucoid.definition: a protein in egg albumen; it inhibits trypsin.

ovotransferrin.definition: a protein in egg albumen; it has metal binding properties.

ovoviviparous.definition: animals that produce eggs with membranes that hatch within the female body and young are born alive, e.g., some reptiles. See Oviparous and Viviparous. 64

ovulation.definition: the release of the ovum from a ruptured ovarian follicle into the body cavity.

ovum_or_ova_(plural).definition: the female reproductive cell formed in the ovary, which consists of a very small genetic nucleus and a very large portion of nutrient yolk material (see Polylecithal), all of which is enclosed in the thin vitelline membrane. The genetic nucleus is seen as the germinal disc on the surface of the yolk and is that part combining with spermatozoa at fertilization.

oyster_shell.definition: small pieces of the shell of oysters that can be used as a source of soluble grit and calcium for bone and eggshell formation. When used, it is commonly fed as a separate supplement.

pad_cooling.definition: an evaporative cooling house which uses wetted pads with fans to move the air into or out of the house.

pair_bonding.definition: development of fidelity between mated birds.

palatability.definition: the acceptability of a feedstuff to the bird. Influenced by taste, smell, moisture, particle shape and texture, color, and previous experience with the feedstuff.

pancreas.definition: a gland located between the duodenal loops of the small intestine. It functions to produce insulin, glucagon, somatostatin and avian pancreatic polypeptides.

panting.definition: rapid and heavy breathing caused by high environmental temperature or physical exertion. Can cause hypocapnia and alkalosis.

pantothenic_acid.definition: a vitamin in the B-complex group that is required for normal hatchability and many other functions.

parasite.definition: an organism that lives within or on another (the host), usually doing harm without any benefit to the host. See External parasites and Internal parasites.

parathyroid.definition: small glands in the neck area near the thyroids that produce a hormone that functions in maintaining blood calcium levels. The primary target organs are bone and kidneys.

paratyphoid.definition: disease produced by a salmonella organism that can cause very high mortality.

parenteral.definition: introduced into the body by some route other than the digestive tract, often by injection.

parrot_beak.definition: an abnormal development of the upper beak in which it is severely curved downward as the beak of a parrot or hawk. Often seen in abnormal embryo conditions such as chondrodystrophy. 65

parson’s_nose.definition: the tail of the processed carcass. Also, Pope’s nose.

parthenogenesis.definition: the development of an embryo from an ovum without fertilization by sperm. Normal in some lower forms but can occur in birds at a very low rate and those embryos are male. In most cases the development is unorganized and minimal, but a few can hatch.

pasted_vents.definition: accumulation of diarrhea-type fecal material or thick urine around the cloacal opening (vent), especially in young chicks, that is usually associated with disease or mismanagement.

pasteurellosis.definition: diseases such as Fowl Cholera caused by the organism Pasteurellia.

pate_de_foie_gras.definition: a paste made from fatty goose livers; considered to be a delicacy.

pathogen.definition: a micro-organism or infective agent that can cause disease.

pathogenicity.definition: the virulence or potential for a pathogen to cause disease.

pathogen_pressure.definition: the severity and number of infectious organisms within the area or environment to which birds are exposed.

pathology.definition: the nature of structural and physiological changes caused by disease, and the field of study dealing with them.

pea_comb.definition: a relatively small, low-set comb that is dominant to Single Comb. It is present in some of the original breeds used for meat production stocks and has been found to be associated with lower fertility.

peafowl.definition: birds of the genus Pavo. The most common domesticated peafowl is Pavo cristatus, which has very large, colorful tail feathers that the male displays. The male is a peacock and the female is a peahen.

peak_production.definition: the point in the egg production period when the rate is at its highest.

peck.definition: strike or pick up with the beak or bill.

pecking_order.definition: a social or aggressive order among a flock of birds in which birds of the higher order peck all those at a lower order. Males and females usually have separate hierarchies. 66

pecten.definition: a very vascular pleated structure with melanin pigmentation that projects from the retina of the avian eye. It appears to function to provide nutrition to the retina through the vitreous body.

pectoral_muscles.definition: the two large muscles of the breast; flight muscles. The large superficial pectoralis major is responsible for drawing the wing downward whereas the smaller deep pectoralis minor is responsible for raising the wing during flight.

pedigree_breeding.definition: a method of selecting breeding stock on performance, which may include the performance of ancestors, siblings and progeny.

pellets.definition: feed that has been compressed into small, rounded particles. Steam is used and heat is produced. See Crumbles.

pelvic_girdle.definition: consists of hip bones and sacral bones and includes the illium, ischium and pubis bones. The bottom of the girdle is open and will expand when the bird is in egg production.

pen.definition: an enclosure for keeping birds. It may have litter, raised wire, or other type of floor. The group of birds in a pen may be referred to as “pen of birds” or “pen-mates”.

penciling.definition: several types of colored lines or markings on feathers.

pendulous_crop.definition: enlarged, bulging crop that, in some cases, is caused by improper and incomplete emptying. The crop contents may become fermented.

penguin_body_position.definition: the abnormal body position of a chicken hen that is similar to that of a penguin. Often seen in hens with accumulated yolks in the body cavity.

perch.definition: a horizontal pole or rod used as a resting place (roost) by birds.

perchery.definition: supplemental perches provided for layers to enable an increased stocking density. Some of the perches may have feeders and water founts.

performance.definition: an economically important, measureable trait of a bird or flock, for example, egg production, body weight gain, feed efficiency, egg weight, mortality, etc.

pericardium.definition: the membranous sac surrounding the heart.

peristalsis.definition: rhythmic, wavelike muscle contractions of the intestinal tract that move the contents through the tract.

peritoneum.definition: the membranous lining of the abdominal cavity.

perosis.definition: deformity of the leg bones resulting in the tendons of the hock joint slipping out of place and twisting of the leg. Common causes are nutritional deficiencies of manganese, choline and perhaps other vitamins.

persistency.definition: the trait of laying at a high rate of production for an extended period of time.

ph.definition: degree of acidity or alkalinity. Expressed as the logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration. Values below 7 are acid and above 7 are alkaline.

phallus.definition: the terminal reproductive organ of the male bird that consists of grooved phallic folds. Size and structure varies with species.

pharynx.definition: opening from the mouth to the larynx.
