pheasant.definition: chicken-like ground dwelling birds that can fly well for short distances. There are many types but the Ringneck pheasant (Phasianus colchicus) is commonly used for meat and hunting preserves. It is native of Asia.

phenotype.definition: visual or performance characteristics of a bird that result from both genetic and environmental influences.

photoperiod.definition: hours of light and dark provided to birds per 24 hours; usually expressed as

photoperiodism.definition: the physiological and behavioral responses of birds to light and changes in time of exposure, light color, light intensity and sequences or patterns of exposure.

photoreceptors.definition: cells or tissues that respond to light photons and convert them into a biological signal. The eye is a receptor for the purpose of vision. In the bird the hypothalamus functions as a receptor for the purpose of reproduction.

photorefractory.definition: the bird, following prolonged exposure to light, becomes less responsive to light stimulation. Recovery of light sensitivity can occur following exposure to short-day lighting for 40 to 80 days.

photosensitive.definition: capability of the bird to respond to light stimulation. Major factors are species, age, previous light exposure, and characteristics of the light.

phylogeny.definition: the development or line of descent of a group of birds such as breed or strain.

physiological_zero.definition: embryonic development is already in progress at the time of oviposition after which it slows as the egg cools. Physiological zero (25 to 27°C; 77 to 80.6°F) is the temperature at which embryonic growth stops as the egg is cooled.

physiology.definition: science pertaining to the functions and vital processes of living organisms. 68

phytase.definition: an enzyme added to poultry diets to catalyze the release of P bound to phytate and improve P utilization.

phytate_phosphorus.definition: P bound to an organic molecule. Organic P.

phytogenic.definition: essential oils and other plant-derived products that when fed have a beneficial effect on the host by influencing intestinal microflora.

pica.definition: an abnormal preference for unusual, unnatural or inedible things to eat.

pickout.definition: damage to the vent, cloaca and oviduct caused by pecking or cannibalism.

pigeon.definition: birds of the Columbidae family that are produced for meat, usually as squab. Other varieties are produced for racing, homing and exhibition.

pigeon_pox.definition: a viral infection of pigeons similar to fowl pox in chickens. A vaccine of pigeon pox has been used against fowl pox in chickens.

pigmentation.definition: color in skin, beak, fat and egg yolks produced by the yellow, xanthophyll- type of pigments in the diet. The intensity of pigmentation in the skin and egg yolks is economically important even though it has little or no effect on nutritional quality.

pineal_gland.definition: a small gland located in the triangular space in the brain between the two cerebral hemispheres and cerebellum. Secretes melatonin in a cycle that is strongly light dependent. Melatonin affects the circadian pacemaker, body temperature cycles, feeding activity, locomotive activity and sleep as well as acting as a scavenger of free radicals.

pin_feathers.definition: a feather just emerging from the skin, usually to replace a feather lost due to molt or accident.

pinion.definition: the last joint of the bird’s wing. Pinioned birds have the last joint removed or bound to restrict flight.

pip,_pipped,_pipping.definition: the act of breaking through the shell by an embryo during the hatching process. “Pips” refers to egg or hatch residue in which the embryo pipped the shell but did not continue the hatching process. An internal pip is an embryo that has pierced the membranes into the air cell but has not pierced the shell (external pip).

piperazine.definition: a type of drug used to treat birds for roundworms.

pituitary.definition: an endocrine gland at the base of the brain that secretes several hormones, including those that stimulate the gonads. It is affected by feedback from the gonads and other glands, especially the hypothalamus, as well as directly or indirectly by light exposure. 69

place.definition: to rank birds or products during judging contests.

placed.definition: moving chicks to brooding areas or farms.

placings.definition: ranking of birds or products during judging contests.

plasma.definition: the fluid, including clotting constituents, remaining after cells have been removed from blood.

pluck.definition: to pull feathers from the skin. May be referred to as pick or picking. Usually done by machine following dipping the dead bird in hot water. Waterfowl may be dipped in hot wax to make plucking easier.

plumage.definition: the feathers or feather covering of a bird.

plymouth_rock.definition: a large breed of chicken of the American Class that is one of the base stocks for meat type commercial birds.

pneumatic_bones.definition: bones into which air sacs extend or which are connected to the tympanic and nasal cavities. Pneumatic bones result in weight reduction of the skeleton, which is an adaptation for flight. Pneumatic bones may include the humerus, coracoid, pelvis, sternum and vertebra.

poikilotherm.definition: an animal that has body temperature that fluctuates with the environmental temperature. Cold blooded. Avian embryos are poikilothermic during most of the embryonic development period. Precocial embryos may develop some homeothermy before hatching, then rapidly thereafter. Altricial embryos develop homeothermy more slowly.

point_of_lay.definition: the period when the bird is physiologically ready to begin egg production. Outward indications in the chicken include enlarged comb and wattles that are bright red and the spreading of the pubic bones as well as the space from the pubic bones to tip of the keel.

pores_(of_shell).definition: very small tubes or holes in the eggshell from the exterior surface to the interior surface. Their shape, size, branching, number and distribution vary with species and strains. The primary function is exchange of gases such as oxygen and carbon dioxide as well as water vapor.

positive_white.definition: permanent white color in the face or earlobes where red is the normal color.

post_mortem_inspection.definition: inspection performed on the carcass of the bird after slaughter.

post_ovulatory_follicle.definition: the ruptured ovarian follicle after the ovum has been released (ovulated). It has some hormone production activity but quickly undergoes atresia and is not comparable to the corpus luteum of mammals. There is some evidence to suggest it produces a homone involved in movement of the egg from the shell gland.

potable.definition: drinkable, implying good quality and safety.

poulard.definition: a young female chicken with ovary(s) removed to cause the bird to have more desirable meat. Not practical for modern commercial meat birds. Plumage patterns and colors resemble those of the male. Compare Capons.

poulet_de_bresse.definition: a specialty meat chicken raised in the Bresse region of France having coral-red combs, white feathers and blue legs. They are range-reared until the last two weeks when they are confined and fed white corn and whole milk.

poult.definition: a young bird, especially turkey or pheasant.

poulterer.definition: one who deals in poultry and game.

poultry.definition: domestic fowl such as chickens, turkeys, guineas, geese and ducks that are raised for meat, eggs, feathers, or other products.

poussin.definition: a meat type chicken processed at an early age and small weight (1 to 2 lb) as a specialty product. Similar to Cornish Game Hen.

pox.definition: viral disease mostly affecting the skin and oral cavity; often species specific; controlled by vaccination.

prebiotics.definition: dietary ingredients that are not hydrolyzed or absorbed by the upper gastrointestinal tract but are fermented by beneficial bacteria in the lower part of the tract and improve the composition of microflora.

precocial.definition: birds that are covered with down at hatching and also are mobile and quickly leave the hatching area. Compare Altricial, Nidicolous, and Nidifugous.

precocious.definition: showing early or premature development, either physical, sexual or mental, beyond that normally expected for the age.

precursor.definition: a preceding substance. In nutrition it is a substance that, following ingestion, is metabolically converted to another substance that is more useful to the animal.

preening.definition: the bird spreads oil from the uropygial or preen gland over the feathers for conditioning and protection of the feathers and to make them more water repellant. 71

preferential_mating.definition: in a flock a male may mate many times with some females but few times or none with other females, thus contributing to infertility.

premix.definition: when ingredients such as vitamins and minerals are used in very small amounts in the diet they are first mixed with a portion of another ingredient, such as ground corn, and then added to the main mixture.

primaries.definition: large wing or flight feathers (remiges) that are attached in the metacarpal and phalangeal area (hand) of the wing. There are approximately 10 in the chicken, but may vary with species. The proximal end of the feather is protected by smaller feathers or coverts.

primary_host.definition: an animal in which a parasite completes its life cycle.

primitive_streak.definition: an early development stage of the avian embryo that appears after approximately 6 to 8 hours of incubation.

processing.definition: 1) related to poultry it refers to the slaughter, defeathering, evisceration, dressing, and cutting into portions of the carcass. Further processing may proceed through cooking and preparation for consumption. 2) Related to eggs it refers to washing, candling, sizing, packaging and, in some cases, breaking and selling as egg products.

production_efficiency.definition: See Feed Conversion Ratio and Feed Efficiency.

productive_energy.definition: energy that is available to the animal for growth, egg production, work or storage.

progeny_test.definition: evaluating or measuring offspring performance to assess the parents.

progesterone.definition: a hormone produced in the walls of the largest follicles in the ovary. It has functions associated with ovulation, production of avidin, and shell formation.

prolapse.definition: the failure of the oviduct, especially the vagina, to return to its proper position after oviposition or egg laying.

proportioner.definition: a device to meter medications or other substances into the drinking water.

protein.definition: organic compounds comprised of amino acids. Required for proper nutrition of the birds, however, formulation is based on individual amino acid requirements when those are known. 72

proteinated.definition: chelation of soluble salt with amino acids or protein.

protozoa.definition: a type of animal, usually one cell and microscopic, that includes the coccidia that cause coccidiosis and the organism (Histomonas meleagridis) that causes Blackhead disease.

proventriculus.definition: the portion of the digestive system that lies between the esophagus and gizzard. The glandular stomach.

psittacosis.definition: the disease Chlamydiosis in psittacine birds.

psychrometer.definition: an instrument having both wet- and dry-bulb thermometers used to determine moisture in the air.

psychrometric_chart.definition: a nomograph used to determine relative humidity, absolute humidity and dew point from wet- and dry-bulb thermometer measurements. Psychrometrics is the relationship between mixtures of air and water vapor at various tempertures.

pteryla.definition: the areas of the skin from which feathers grow. Also Feather Tracts. For

detailed_descriptions_of_feathers_and_fe.term: detailed descriptions of feathers and feather tracts see
detailed_descriptions_of_feathers_and_fe.definition: Lucas, A. M., and P. R. Stettenheim, 1972. Avian Anatomy – Integument, Parts I and II. Agriculture Handbook 362. U.S. Government Printing Office, Washington, D.C.

pubis.definition: part of the pelvic girdle. The distance between the thin ends of the pubic bones is used as an indicator of productivity of the hen.

pufa.definition: polyunsaturated fatty acids. See also MUFA.

pullet.definition: a female chicken less than one year old. May be applied to those prior to the age of sexual maturity (beginning of egg production) or to those through one year of egg production.

pullorum.definition: a disease caused by Salmonella pullorum resulting in high mortality in young birds. It can be transmitted through the egg from the hen, contamination of the egg, and in contaminated feed. Prevented by proper sanitation and by blood-testing the breeder stock to identify and remove those carrying the organism.

purebred.definition: the offspring of a cock and hen of the same breed.

pygostyle.definition: the fused bone at the tip of the tail (coccygeal vertebrae).

pyridoxine.definition: a B-complex vitamin (B ). A deficiency results in inhibition of early embryonic 6 growth with mortality peaks days 8 to 14. 73

pyrogen.definition: a substance that can cause a fever.

quail.definition: small gallinaceous game birds of various types found on most continents. The Bobwhite, native to North America, has economic value for meat and hunting. Several other types of quail are also indigenous to North America. Coturnix or Japanese quail have economic value for both meat and egg production. Coturnix are migratory, Bobwhite are not.

quail_bronchitis.definition: a viral respiratory infection of quail that often causes high mortality. Although distinct from infectious bronchitis of chickens, it has many of the same lesions and clinical signs.

qualitative_restriction.definition: control of nutrient intake by the feeding of lower quality diets.

quantitative_restriction.definition: control of nutrient intake by feeding reduced amounts of the diet or by reduced feeding time.

quarantine.definition: the maintenance of birds in isolation for a specified period of time to determine if they have an infection, to prevent the spread of infection, or other purpose in the biosecurity system of a poultry operation.

quaternary_ammonium_compounds.definition: a group of chemicals commonly used in poultry operations as disinfectants.

quill.definition: the hollow base portion (calamus) of large, mature feathers. It contains a blood supply in the growing feather and the tip is embedded in the feather follicle of the skin.

rachis.definition: the portion of the feather shaft having barbs and barbules.

radiation.definition: heat transmission from warmer to cooler surfaces by waves without physical contact of the heat source and the receiving object.

radius.definition: the smaller of the two bones of the forearm of the wing.

rale.definition: an abnormal sound, as rattling or bubbling, during breathing that usually indicates a respiratory disease condition.

random_sample_test.definition: a type of performance comparison in which random samples of birds from commercial sources are placed in the same facilities with the same management and environment. The test may be with either meat or egg production type birds.

range_production.definition: birds for meat or egg production are maintained with free access to pasture.

range_shelter.definition: a structure, usually portable, that has a roof with or without side walls and perches to provide shelter for birds on pasture. 74

ration.definition: the amount of feed allowed per day or time period. See Diet.

ratite.definition: member of the group of flightless birds that includes ostrich, emu, cassowary, kiwi and rhea. Some are commercially produced.

ready_to_cook_(rtc).definition: processed young poultry and its parts which are ready to be cooked with very little additional preparation.

recessiveness.definition: the allele in a heterozygote that is suppressed by its partner and is expressed only in the homozygous state.

reciprocal_mating.definition: crossing two strains or groups in two ways, i.e., A males with B females and B males with A females.

recombinant.definition: an individual in which recombination has occurred.

recombination.definition: the presence of new gene combinations in an individual not present in either parent and may be introduced from other organisms.

recrudesence.definition: the regrowth or rejuvenation or a tissue, organ or system after it has regressed. An example is the reproductive system rejuvenation following a feather molt.

red_blood_cell.definition: the blood cell that contains hemoglobin and a primary function of carrying oxygen to the body tissues. The avian red blood cell is nucleated.

red_hocks.definition: a condition in hatching chicks in which the hocks become reddened in prolonged struggle to hatch. There are numerous causes.

red_mite.definition: an arachnid parasite, very small, that feeds on the blood of the bird at night but does not stay on the bird during the day.

refractoriness.definition: unresponsive to a stimulus, e.g., light. See Photorefractory.

relative_humidity.definition: the amount of moisture in the air compared to the maximum that it could hold at that temperature. Usually expressed as a percentage.

remiges.definition: the large flight feathers of the wing. See Primaries and Secondaries.

renal_portal_system.definition: venous circulation in which blood from the legs and lower intestines is diverted through the kidneys before returning to the heart. A consideration in procedures in which substances are injected into the legs. 75

resistant.definition: when used in regard to antibiotics or drugs, it indicates that the micro- organism is affected less than expected, or not at all, by a specific substance.

respiratory_system.definition: consists of the primary parts: trachea, bronchi, lungs and air sacs. The avian lung is a flow-through system with air passing through to the air sacs and returning through the lungs in exhalation. The main functions are oxygen and carbon dioxide exchange in the lungs, vocalization in the syrinx, and thermoregulation, mostly by evaporative heat loss. The lungs do not expand and contract.

resting_metabolic_rate_(rmr).definition: metabolic rate measured when birds are in their thermoneutral zone and resting but not fasting. See Basal metabolic rate.

restricted_or_controlled_feeding.definition: regulation of feed intake to maintain a desired growth rate, body weight or other characteristic. Restriction may be in the form of reduced daily intake or skipped feeding on one or more days per week in various patterns. Restriction may also be in the form of quality of the diet.

rhea.definition: a large non-flying ratite bird of South American origin, smaller than ostrich and emu, that is sometimes used for meat production.

rhode_island_red.definition: a base stock of chickens of the American Class used for commercial production of brown eggs; also a useful stock for home flocks.

riboflavin.definition: a vitamin of the B-complex. A deficiency causes stunting of the embryo with multiple abnormalities and high mortality.

rice_hulls.definition: a by-product of rice grain production that can be used as a litter material.

rickets.definition: abnormal bone growth resulting from dietary deficiencies or imbalance of vitamin D, calcium and phosphorus.

ridge_ventilation.definition: an opening is left at the peak or ridge of the roof allowing warm air to passively rise out of the house. Fans may be placed in a closed-ridge roof to provide forced ridge ventilation.

rigor_mortis.definition: the stiffening of muscles following death. It is an important consideration in processing and tenderness of the muscle.

roaster.definition: a young male or female chicken that is suitable for cooking whole in an oven; usually larger than a “broiler”, averaging 4 to 6 lb.

roche_fan.definition: a color scale for measuring yolk pigment level or intensity.

roost.definition: a place with perches for birds to rest or sleep. 76

rooster.definition: a male chicken. See Cock and Cockerel.

rose_comb.definition: a type of small, compact comb that is dominant to single comb.

roundworm.definition: Ascaridia galli is one of the most common poultry worm parasites. Generally found in the central part of the intestine. Worm infestations have been reported to be associated with reduced allergenic reactions. See Ascarid.

run.definition: an area outside of the house to allow outdoor activity.

r_value.definition: a measure of the ability of materials to resist the transfer of heat.

rye.definition: a cereal grain that can be used as a feed ingredient.

saddle.definition: the rear of the back extending to the tail feathers and covered with long, pointed feathers (saddle feathers) in the male.

salmonellosis.definition: a disease caused by one of the bacteria of the Salmonella type. See Pullorum, Paratyphoid and Fowl typhoid or Typhoid.

salt.definition: the chemical sodium chloride (NaCl) that is required in the diet.

salt_glands_or_nasal_glands.definition: glands located on the beak near the nares and eyes that function to remove excess salt from the blood (osmoregulatory) and are controlled by osmoreceptors. Occurs more commonly in marine birds; may be present but non- functional in some species.

sanitation.definition: maintaining healthful and disease free conditions through cleanliness, treatment of the environment with anti-microbial agents, prompt removal of wastes and other preventative measures.

satiety.definition: having had enough, e.g., having eaten until full or satisfied.

scabby_hip_syndrome.definition: injuries of the back and hip areas of meat birds, usually caused by toe nail scratches and results in downgrading of carcasses.

scald.definition: dipping birds in hot water (approximately 128 to 140°F) for a specific time to loosen feathers for plucking.

scales.definition: horny, thin, flat plates of tissue covering the shanks and feet.

scaly_leg.definition: scales on the legs and feet may be raised with encrustations. Caused by a type of mite (arachnid) that burrows under the scales. Can be controlled by treatment with oils.

scotophase.definition: the period of darkness between dusk and dawn or lights-off and lights-on (light/dark interphase to dark/light interphase). 77

scratch.definition: the habit of chickens and some other birds of scraping their claws across the ground to uncover food.

scratch_feed.definition: whole grain, cracked grain or pellets that are scattered on the litter or ground in some feeding systems, especially small poultry units.

seasonal_breeder.definition: a bird that is in an active reproductive state during a specific season of the year. Commonly respond to light as the determining factor, however, temperature, rainfall, food availability and other factors may be the primary determinant.

sebum.definition: the oily substance secreted by the uropygial gland and a few sebaceous glands. See Uropygial Gland.

secondaries.definition: a second group of large wing flight feathers located nearer to the body than the primaries and which cover the primaries when the wing is normally folded.

secondary_sexual_characteristics.definition: differences between females and males such as feather color and shape, comb size and shape, pubic bone separation, body size, behavior and voice.

second_cycle_hens.definition: laying hens that have been force-rested and are in the post-rest or post-molt laying period.

secretion.definition: to form and release from a gland or tissue, e.g., albumen in the oviduct.

selenium.definition: an essential dietary element in small amounts; a deficiency can cause the accumulation of fluid under the skin and mortality in embryos. Large amounts can be toxic.

sensible_heat.definition: heat that can be felt by the body. Heat that causes an increase in temperature when absorbed by a body.

sentinel_birds.definition: susceptible birds placed in near proximity to other birds to detect latent infections or introduced infections.

septicemia.definition: a systemic infection in the blood; may include toxins from the bacteria.

serological_test.definition: examination of blood serum to determine the presence and quantity of antibodies for a specific pathogen.

serum.definition: the clear fluid remaining after all cells and clotting constituents are removed from blood.

set_or_setting.definition: 1) to place eggs in an incubator for incubation for approximately 18 days (chicken) before moving to another machine for hatching. 2) May also refer to a batch of eggs that were set together. 78

setter.definition: the incubator or incubation machine in which eggs are placed for incubation for approximately 18 days (chicken) prior to moving to a hatcher.

sex_chromosome.definition: the pair of chromosomes (designated as Z and W in the bird) that determine the gender of the individual. In the bird the female is the heterozygote (ZW), thus determining gender of the offspring, whereas the male is the homozygote (ZZ).

sexing.definition: determining the gender of a chick (or older bird) by cloacal examination, feather color, feather length, instrument or DNA. See Sexor and Sexing scope.

sexing_scope.definition: an instrument similar to a proctoscope used to view the testes through the large intestine wall to determine gender of the chick.

sex_linked.definition: characters that are associated with one gender due to the gene being located on the sex chromosome. Some of these characters can be used to identify the sex of a chick at hatching (auto-sexing).

sex_ratio.definition: the proportion of males and females in a group. The primary sex ratio is the proportion at the time of fertilization. The secondary sex ratio is the proportion at the time of hatching and is influenced by embryo mortality. The tertiary sex ratio is the proportion at any given time after hatching. The primary and secondary ratios will usually approximate

1.definition: 1, however, the secondary ration will tend to be skewed toward more females in chicks hatched from older breeder flocks.

sexor.definition: a person who determines the gender of a newly hatched chick or other bird. Usually done by examination of the cloacal anatomy, feather growth or feather color.

sex_reversal.definition: a gender change, usually from female to male. It may involve phenotype change only or functional changes in which the left ovary becomes nonfunctional and the right ovary develops some testes-like tissue. Usually considered a pathological condition.

sexual_dimorphism.definition: differences between males and females in appearance, physiology and production.

sexual_maturity.definition: the age at which the female first lays an egg and the male produces semen that is capable of fertilizing an egg. Varies widely among domestic species (e.g., 7 to 8 weeks of age for Japanese quail and 28 to 30 weeks for turkeys).

shackles.definition: metal or plastic hangers which hold poultry securely by the feet during processing

shaft.definition: the quill of a large feather, including the portion to which barbs are attached.

shank.definition: the lower portion of the leg, usually covered with scales. It is the tarsometatarsus connecting the toes to the tibia. 79

sheen.definition: the luster, glossy or glistening effect seen on the feathers, often appearing green or purple and influenced by lighting.

shell_gland.definition: the sac-like portion of the oviduct in which the forming egg spends about 20 hours during which the shell is secreted and formed. Sometimes called Uterus. See Oviduct.

shell_membrane.definition: consists of two membranes. The outer membrane lines the inner surface of the shell, whereas the inner membrane surrounds the egg albumen. A space may form between the membranes at the large end of the egg, which is called the air space or air cell that has an important embryonic function in the hatching process. See Air cell.

short_day.definition: a daylength that is insufficient to stimulate hormone release and gonadal growth.

shoulder_girdle.definition: the group of bones that connect at the anterior, dorsal part of the body and includes the clavicle, scapula and coracoid to which the wing (humerus) is attached.

shuttle_program.definition: switching among treatment medications to avoid increased resistance.

sib_testing.definition: evaluation of the breeding potential of an individual based on performance of its siblings as well as its own performance.

sickles.definition: the large curved feathers of the tail of the mature male chicken. They may be separated into primary or main (prominent uppermost pair) and lesser sickles.

side_sprig.definition: a pointed growth on the side of a single comb.

side_ventilation.definition: poultry houses designed with air intakes along the side. Exhausts may also be on the opposite side to result in cross-ventilation.

sieve.definition: a tool for separating small from large particles, often consisting of screens with various size openings.

silkie.definition: the type of feather characteristic of the Silkie breed in which the barbs of the feathers are not locked together thus giving the feather a fluffy texture.

silver_and_gold.definition: plumage colors in which Silver is dominant to Gold. The alleles are sex- linked and can be used as auto-sexing characters to determine the sex of the chick at hatching.

single_comb.definition: a comb type having a “blade” that is usually large and vertical in the male. It is recessive to Rose and Pea Combs. 80

single_stage_incubation.definition: an incubation system or incubator that contains only one age of embryo. It allows more precise control of age-appropriate environmental conditions for the embryos. See Incubator and Multistage incubation.

sinus.definition: cavities within bone or tissue, but commonly referring to the cavities in the skull that open into the nasal passages.

sire_family.definition: offspring of a cock mated with 1 or more hens, so that all are full or half siblings.

sitting.definition: to sit upon and incubate eggs. The hen that sits on eggs is a “sitting hen” or a “broody hen” and exhibits broodiness behavior. [A “set” of eggs may be placed under a “sitting” hen for her to “sit” on them during incubation]

skein.definition: a flock of wild fowl, especially geese.

skeletal_photoperiod.definition: a light period interrupted by one or more short dark periods that the bird senses as a single light period.

skeleton.definition: the bones of the body; the bony framework that supports all other organs and tissues.

skin.definition: the organ comprising the outer covering of the body. See Integument.

slatted_floor.definition: a floor constructed of strips of wood, plastic or other appropriate material on which birds can stand but that is open enough for the feces to fall through to a collection pit below.

slip.definition: a male in which the caponizing procedure failed to completely remove all of both testes.

small_intestine.definition: that part of the intestine from the gizzard to the ceca-large intestine junction. It includes the duodeum, jejunum and ileum.

snood.definition: a protuberance on the head of a turkey that functions in displays, becoming elongated and hanging down on one side of the face.

soft_shelled_eggs.definition: eggs laid with little or no calcareous shell.

somites.definition: block-like segments of mesoderm that first appear in the embryo at about 22 hours of incubation and will give rise to bones, muscles, etc. 81

sorghum.definition: a small grain that can be used as a substitute for maize in diets.

sour_crop.definition: a disorder of the crop that often involves fermentation of the contents.

soybean_meal.definition: a feed ingredient produced from soybeans that have been processed to remove oil and to inactivate the anti-nutritional factors of the raw bean. It is a very common feed ingredient as a primary source of protein and secondary source of energy. Feeding unprocessed soybeans may result in enlarged pancreas and other problems.

spangling.definition: a black v-shaped tip to silver or gold feathers or white tip to dark feathers. More feathers affected than in Mottling.

species.definition: a group of organisms having many characteristics in common and usually can interbreed; a subdivision of genus.

spectacles.definition: small plastic shields or blinders that can be attached to the beak of hens at the nares to restrict forward vision and reduce cannibalism, feather-pulling and egg eating.

spectrum.definition: the range of colors in light.

spent_hens.definition: laying hens that have completed their laying cycle(s) and are to be replaced by a young flock.

spermatogenesis.definition: the process of formation of sperm, including both spermatocytogenesis and spermiogenesis.

spermatozoa_or_sperm.definition: the male gamete produced in the testes in the process of spermatogenesis. Deposited in the vagina of the hen at mating and can be stored there for several days.

sphincter.definition: a ring-shaped muscle around an opening of the body or an organ, which can open or close the opening.

spleen.definition: a reddish-brown organ located near the liver that is involved in the immune system and blood filtration.

spike.definition: 1) addition of males to a breeding flock during the breeding cycle. 2) The tapered, cone shaped, rear portion of the rose comb.

spore.definition: a reproductive cell of some fungi and other organisms. They are usually resistant to disinfectants, heat and drying.

sport.definition: a bird having a changed appearance from normal due to a mutation.

spraddler.definition: young chick with legs spread apart (splay) rendering it incapable of standing.

spur.definition: a stiff, horn-like projection on the inside of the shank, primarily in males. Spur growth is influenced by the sex of the bird but is independent of sex hormones. 82

squab.definition: young pigeon still in the nest.

squat_or_squatting.definition: a position in which the hen crouches close to the ground in accepting the approach of a male for mating.

stag.definition: a male. Specifically, a male turkey or tom.

standard_breed.definition: a breed of birds that are of a “normal” or large size in comparison to bantams. See Bantams.

staphylococcosis.definition: infection caused by any of the many Staphylococcus organisms.

started_pullets.definition: young females that are approaching the beginning of egg production and sexual maturity.

starter_diet.definition: the diet formulated to meet the requirements of the growing chick during the first days or weeks of life.

starve_outs.definition: young birds that never eat sufficiently to survive after exhausting the residual yolk.

static_pressure.definition: the difference between inside house and outside atmospheric pressure; can be either positive or negative in the poultry house, depending on whether the fans are blowing air into the house or exhausting from the house.

sterilize.definition: 1) to remove the reproductive organs or to render them nonfunctional. 2) Also, to remove or kill all microorganisms, often by heat.

sternum.definition: the breast bone. See also Keel.

sticky_chicks.definition: chicks that hatch with albumen smeared over the down that often is caused by low incubation temperature, high humidity, improper turning and poor quality eggs.

stigma.definition: the rupture line on the ovarian follicular membrane.

still_air_incubator.definition: small incubators that have no fans to circulate air but depend on convection currents to achieve adequate ventilation.

straight_run.definition: chicks have not been separated by gender after hatching, but unthrifty chicks may have been removed. Also called “As-Hatched”.

strain.definition: a group of birds in which breeding and selection has occurred for several generations without the introduction of new stock. 83

strain_cross.definition: birds resulting from the crossing of two or more strains. Many commercial birds are strain crosses.

streptococcosis.definition: disease conditions caused by the organism, Streptococcus zooepidemicus.

stress.definition: responses of the animal that include increased adrenal hormones, immunosuppression, decreased reproduction or growth and numerous other physiological reactions to factors or stressors such as disease, malnutrition, adverse environments, noises, crowding, injury, etc.

strutting.definition: a part of the courting behavior of male turkeys, often accompanied by trumpeting vocal calls.

stub.definition: 1) a feather beginning to grow or one that has been broken. Stubbing is the process of removing the stub during processing. 2) Down or feather on the shank or toe of a clean legged bird.

stuck_chick.definition: chicks that become stuck in the shell during the hatching process or hatch with shell fragments stuck to the down feathers. Similar to Sticky chick.

supplement.definition: nutritive substances such as vitamins and minor minerals added to the major base ingredients of the diet. See Additives.

swan.definition: large, long-necked, web-footed waterfowl of the genus Cygnus. Domestic use is primarily ornamental.

sympathetic_and_parasympathetic_systems.definition: parts of the involuntary or autonomic nervous system that regulate and affect numerous organs and tissues.

synbiotics.definition: foods with both prebiotic and probiotic properties as health-enhancing foods.

syndactylism.definition: having abnormal webbing between the toes.

syndrome.definition: a set of characteristics or signs that are used to identify a disease condition, often before the cause is known.

synovitis.definition: infectious synovitis or mycoplasma synoviae (MS) caused by an infection by Mycoplasma synoviae that particularly affects joints of legs and wings. Can be prevented by flock monitoring and quarantine procedures.

syrinx.definition: that portion of the upper respiratory tract at the bifurcation of the trachea into the primary bronchi; the site of vocalization in birds. In some species there is an additional resonant apparatus, which has variable structure among species. 84

tainted.definition: in regard to meat and eggs it refers to being affected by odors, contaminations, infections, dirt, chemicals, etc.

tapeworms,_cestodes.definition: flat, white, ribbon-like, segmented parasites of the intestine. Require an intermediate host such as earthworms.

taste.definition: the sensing of flavor; one of the chemically based senses.

t_cells.definition: lymphocytes originating in the thymus that function in recognition and killing of abnormal cells, and assist B-cells.

tenderloin.definition: this boneless, skinless white meat is the pectoralis minor muscle. It comes from the inside of the breast adjacent to the keel bone.

tendon.definition: tough, fibrous connective tissue connecting muscles to bone or other tissue.

testis.definition: the male gonad. See Male reproductive system.

therapeutic.definition: healing or curative. A drug given at a therapeutic dose may also be prophylactic or preventative.

thermoneutral_zone_(tnz).definition: an ambient temperature in which a bird does not spend energy for active evaporative cooling or regulatory thermogenesis. See Basal metabolic rate. The upper and lower boundaries of the TNZ are upper critical and lower critical temperatures, respectively. The TNZ will vary with species, size, acclimatization and other factors.

thermoregulation.definition: control of body temperature by changing heat production, heat transport, heat exchange, etc.

thiamine.definition: a B-complex vitamin (B ). A deficiency may result in polyneuritis, high embryo 1 mortality and many dead chicks in hatching trays.

thick_albumen.definition: the third layer of albumen out from the yolk. It is heavy, thick and contains many mucin fibers giving the albumen shape; it is attached to the inner shell membrane at both ends of the egg. See Albumen.

thigh.definition: the upper leg, with femur bone, between the knee and the body (pelvic girdle). 85

thin_albumen.definition: two layers of albumen (the inner thin is between the chalizerous and thick albumen layers and the outer thin is between the thick albumen and the inner shell membrane around the equatorial area of the egg) that contain few mucin fibers. See Albumen.

thoracic_cavity.definition: the chest area containing heart and lungs. There is no diaphragm in birds separating the thoracic cavity from the Abdominal cavity.

threshold.definition: the level or point at which a stimulus is adequate to cause the first observable response.

throat.definition: the front part of the neck including the upper part of the passage from the mouth and nose to the crop and lungs.

throw.definition: when describing negative ventilation systems, it is the distance an air jet travels from the air inlet before its maximum air speed is reduced to 75 fpm.

thrush.definition: an infection of the mouth, esophagus and crop caused by a Candida fungus. See Candidiasis.

thymus.definition: a gland located along the neck that decreases in size with maturity. It has a major role in the immune system and development of immunity. Source of T-cells (T- lymphocytes).

thyroid.definition: paired glands in the neck that function to regulate metabolism, growth and feathering. Produces triiodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine or tetraiodothyronine (T4).

tibia.definition: the primary bone of the lower leg (drumstick).

tibial_dyschondroplasia.definition: a developmental abnormality of the leg, especially in broilers.

time_clock.definition: the clock-like mechanism used to control lighting, ventilation or other regularly occurring events.

titer.definition: the weakest dilution in which clumping of the antigen will occur in an agglutination test.

torpidity.definition: dormant or inactive; sluggish metabolism and activity.

torpor.definition: the state of being dormant or inactive. See Torpidity.

toxemia.definition: toxins, usually from micro-organisms, have been absorbed and are in the blood.

toxin.definition: a poisonous material, usually from a biological source.

trachea.definition: the respiratory tract tube extending from the larynx to the bifurcation into bronchi; also called windpipe.

transgenesis.definition: transfer of genetic material from one organism to another.

trapnest.definition: a nest used in pedigree breeding which holds the hen until identified and released.

treading.definition: mounting of the female by the male during mating.

trematodes.definition: leaflike flatworms (flukes) that may afflict various parts of the body but are not usually a serious problem. Require snails as an intermediate host.

trussing.definition: tying the wings and shaping poultry before cooking.

tumor.definition: a swelling or abnormal growth that may be benign or malignant.

tunnel_ventilation.definition: a closed house having forced ventilation with air inlets in one end of the house and outlets at the other end. In positive pressure houses the fans are in the inlets pushing air into the house. In negative pressure houses the fans exhaust air from the house. Generally, a negative pressure system is used in commercial poultry houses.

turkey.definition: birds of any of the subspecies of Meleagris gallopavo, native to N. America and domesticated by the American Indians. Domestic turkeys are very large, cannot fly and are artificially inseminated on a commercial basis. They produce a high percentage of white (breast) meat.

turning_(of_eggs).definition: eggs are turned in nature by the brooding bird and in incubators by automatic turning mechanisms. Eggs are normally turned one to four times per hour from setting until 18 days of incubation (chicken). The most crucial time seems to be from two to seven days. The ideal frequency, angle and embryo age for egg turning may vary with species, strain, breeder age, type of machine and other factors.

typhoid.definition: disease caused by Salmonella gallinarum usually in growing or mature birds. See Fowl typhoid and Salmonellosis.

ulcerative_enteritis.definition: a type of enteritis caused by Clostridium colinum in quail and sometimes other species. May cause very high mortality in domestic quail. 87

ulna.definition: the larger distal bone in the wing

ultimobranchial_gland.definition: two small glands located in the neck near the branch of the brachiocephalic artery. Produces calcitonin which affects bone resorption and renal calcium and phosphorus excretion.

umbilicus.definition: 1) the place where the blood vessels supplying the embryonic membranes (yolk sac, chorioallantois and amnion) pass through the body wall. Just prior to hatching the yolk sac is withdrawn into the abdominal cavity and the umbilicus closes and heals as the vessels to the other membranes dry up. See Navel. 2) The opening to that part of the feather calamus embedded in the feather follicle is known as the proximal umbilicus whereas the opening in the feather shaft at the junction of the calamus and rachis is the distal umbilicus.

unabsorbed_yolk.definition: the yolk material remaining in the withdrawn yolk sac at hatching. After hatching it moves directly into the small intestine and is quickly absorbed. The stalk attaching the yolk sac to the intestine remains in the older bird. It is called Meckel’s diverticulum and is thought to have some immune system functions.

undercolor.definition: the color of the fluff portion of body feathers near the skin.

undergrade.definition: edible shell eggs that do not meet the requirements (standards) for Grade AA, Grade A, Grade B or Checks.

ureters.definition: tubes transporting urine from the kidney to the cloaca.

uric_acid,_urates.definition: the insoluble and primary nitrogen waste product of the bird. A probable adaptation necessary for embryonic development in the shell. Urea is the soluble form of nitrogen waste found in many animals.

uropygial_gland.definition: also known as the preen gland or oil gland, it is located under the skin of the back at the place where the tail extends from the back. It is bilobed and secretes a holocrine oily substance (sebum) that the bird uses to preen or dress the feathers to prevent them from drying out and to waterproof them.

usda_grade_a.definition: ready-to-cook products graded for quality according to official standards administered by the USDA, Agricultural Marketing Service, Poultry Programs. The product conforms to the requirements for “A” quality.

uterus.definition: see Shell Gland. It has little in common with the mammalian uterus. 88

utility_or_dual_purpose_strain.definition: a type of bird that is useful for both egg and meat production.

vaccine.definition: a preparation of dead or attenuated (live but non-virulent) micro-organisms, or proteins from them, which when introduced into the body initiates the development of immunity against that micro-organism or toxin.

vagina.definition: the posterior portion of the oviduct. Main functions include oviposition, site of sperm deposition and storage, addition of some cuticle material to the egg. See Oviduct.

valgus.definition: an abnormal condition in which the legs are bent or twisted outward.

vane.definition: the part of a feather consisting of barbs, barbules and barbicels that forms the wide portion of the feather on either side of the shaft or rachis.

variety.definition: a subdivision of a breed; usually distinguished by comb type, feather color or feather pattern. See Breed.

vas_deferens.definition: the convoluted white tube that carries semen from the epididymis of the testes to the phallus in the cloaca.

vector.definition: an animal or insect that carries or transmits a disease or parasite from one host to another. Compare Fomite.

vein.definition: that part of the circulatory system that carries blood back to the heart.

vent.definition: the external opening of the cloaca. See Cloaca.

ventilate.definition: the movement of air in, through and out of a space.

ventral.definition: the underneath portion of the body as opposed to dorsal or back.

vent_sexing.definition: a procedure for determining the sex of newly hatched poultry by examination of the cloacal anatomy. See Sexor and Sexing.

vertical_integration.definition: in the poultry industry a company (Integrator) would have breeder multiplier flocks (probably contract producers), hatchery, pullet or broiler grower farms (usually contract producers), broiler or egg processing plants, egg production farms (probably contract), feed mill, transportation units, marketing units, and related operations. These are sometimes referred to as broiler or layer complexes. Also defined as when two or more dissimilar enterprises, such as a feed mill and a hatchery, are combined in the production, processing or marketing of a product.

viability.definition: ability to live and develop. See Mortality. 89

vices.definition: bad behaviors that include cannibalism, feather pulling, toe-pecking, egg eating, flightiness, hysteria, etc.

viral_arthritis.definition: a reovirus infection that affects tendons, synovial membranes and the heart. The condition is more apparent in larger birds.

virulence.definition: highly infectious and able to overcome natural defenses.

virus.definition: very small microscopic agents causing diseases including Infectious Bronchitis, Newcastle Disease and Fowl Pox. Capable of multiplying only inside a living cell.

viscera.definition: the organs and tissue within the abdominal and thoracic body cavities.

visible_radiation.definition: that portion of the electromagnetic spectrum having wavelengths to which the eye is sensitive, lying between ultraviolet and infrared wavelengths.

vitamin.definition: several unrelated organic substances required in small amounts by the body for normal metabolism and development that are provided in the diet or, in a few cases, may be synthesized in the body.

vitamin_mineral_premix.definition: a mixture of vitamin and minerals in appropriate proportions to supply those ingredients in a complete diet. Generally promotes efficiency and accuracy in the feed mixing process.

vitelline_membrane.definition: the non-cellular membrane that surrounds the yolk material and blastoderm of the egg yolk. Two inner layers are ovary-derived and 2 outer layers are oviduct-derived. The outer 3 layers are coatings on the inner layer, which is the vitelline membrane.

viviparous.definition: type of animal that brings forth living young, e.g., mammals. See Oviparous and Ovoviviparous.

walnut_comb.definition: small type comb resulting from the presence of rose and pea genes. Interbreeding can give birds with walnut, pea, rose or single combs.

waltz.definition: a common part of the courting behavior of male chickens.

waterfowl.definition: swimming birds; in domestic birds this includes ducks, geese and swans.

water_glass.definition: sodium silicate when mixed with water forms a clear, thick liquid that historically was used to preserve eggs.

wattles.definition: structures of flesh and skin hanging from the chin or throat of birds such as chickens, turkeys and a few other species. It is often red, blue or yellow and is larger in males. 90
